description:
We had a terriic dinner a couple of nights, ago!  We don't live anywhere near downtown SF so it's a bit of drive for us.  But, it was well worth the effort.

We started with a complimentary amuse-bouche (appetizer) of Speck (smoked Prosciutto) on toast with grape tomato and pea puree.  Then we ordered and shared an appetizer of Ginger Crispy Chicken Lollipops on a bed of Napa Slaw.  I had the special Risotto with Duck Confit & Italian Sausage.  My wife had Chinese Five Spice Short Ribs.

We had two glasses of J. Loher 2008 Merlot.  It was an outstanding pairing with the short ribs!  We finished with a fresh fruit short cake and coffee.

We had excellent service by Jason.

We would go back if we're in The City near the downtown area.

The food and service were outstanding and they feature organic and sustainable, local, food ingredients.

They're located in the Orchid Hotel, the most Eco-friendly hotel in SF.
author: James Q.

description:
Unilaterally not worth the price. Over $20 for breakfast which amounted to runny scrambled eggs and poor service. My heart goes out to the waitress, who staffs a room that looks like it seats fifty people, alone. She is the cashier, the waitress, and she busses the tables. So, if you were hoping for a refill on your drink, forget it. I was seated in a row of tables, three of which no longer had anyone at them and they needed to be bussed. 

Also, there is a language barrier issue. Since the restaurant only serves breakfast, as long as you stick to ordering one of the ten available selections, there's no issue. But, if you want the check split or combined, you'll have a problem. 

With breakfast selections widely available elsewhere, and for cheaper, this place is a definite skip.
author: Kathryne B.

description:
Got a great deal for 30% off the bill w/ no printout coupons needed if you reserve through Savored! Good location as it's near Union, close to shopping, most people's offices.

It was weird eating dinner there on Friday as the restaurant was COMPLETELY empty. But whatever, we had a good meal at a good price. And although the server said they were closing shop at 9pm, he stayed on and served us long afterwards.

* Wild Arugula Salad
(Chioggia Beets, Baby Artichokes & Meyer Lemon Vinaigrette - $11)
- 3.5 stars
Had a little taste. Just enough of the tangy dressing, well balanced. My friend who ordered this loved it. I think it could have used more components to have a greater variety of textures and flavors

* Orchard Kobe Burger 
(Havarti Cheese, Spicy Aioli, House Made Pickles & Fries - $15)
- 4 stars
The patty was fantastic. I said medium rare, on the rare side, and I got exactly that. It was juicy and tender, and the melted cheese on top was fantastic. The only downside is the bun, which was really quite dry. Fries were thin, and they were pretty good.

* Organic English Pea  Risotto 
(Roasted Beets, Fennel & Parmigiano-Reggiano - $19)
- 3 stars
The risotto had a great creamy texture and wonderful flavor. The beets were just awkward because there were about 5 GIANT chunks surrounding the risotto. It could have been chopped smaller and actually cooked into the risotto so we didn't have to break off chunks with our forks and manually add some to each bite.

* Pizza of the Day  
(Artichoke & sausage - $12)
- 2 stars
This didn't stand out much. The crust seemed too hard and stale, and there wasn't enough tomato sauce so there wasn't something to counter the cheese & other toppings.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
This is a small restaurant in the Orchard Hotel. We had the flat iron steak, one serving  with hand cut French fries & the other with Swiss chard. Everything was absolutely delicious. The service and ambiance was perfect. 

This is a great place.
author: John D.

description:
Had an early dinner with my girlfriend. The place was completely empty when we got in around 5-6 pm. The restaurant is in the lobby of a hotel. 

Service was good despite being understaffed. We were allowed to substitute wine with mixed drinks, which was nice since we're not much of wine drinkers. And they were kind enough to let us substitute the cheese plate with desserts.

Food was delicious. We shared a salad, five spice short ribs, the salmon, and the chocolate dessert. And on the house, they gave us a couple slices of bread topped with what I believe was liver. 

TravelZoo Voucher made this experience worthwhile. If it weren't for the voucher, this would have been quite an expensive meal, albeit, satisfying.
author: S T.

description:
Fortunately, we had a restaurant.com gift certificate for this restaurant so we were at least somewhat satisfied with out dining experience but the full price of our meal would not have been worth it at all!  

Atmosphere:
-Modern decor; small restaurant located and open to the hotel's lobby; intimate

Service:
-Friendly and helpful staff but kitchen service is a bit slow...we waited quite awhile for our food and at least 15 to 20 minutes just for dessert

Food:
Pasto Anti (prosciutto/ grilled bread/ truffle tremor/ fruit/ olives)
-small portions. bread was too hard. not the best prosciutto I've had.

Beef Bourguignon over pasta
-Pieces of meat were not that tender, juicy, or tasty. 

Catch of the day: Halibut
-Fish was a bit overcooked and overly salted. Fish was fresh though.

House Spun Ice Cream & Sorbets (3 scoops)
-We got a scoop of burnt almond ice cream, a scoop of mango sorbet, and a scoop of lemon sorbet. Burnt almond flavor was creamy and not too sweet. Mango sorbet was delicious but the lemon flavor was way too sour. 

For the price of their menu, I would expect much better quality. The food was definitely mediocre at best.
author: Angela F.

description:
This review is for their breakfast options. I stayed at the hotel and had breakfast here two times. Service was fairly quick and attentive.

The five stars is for their consistently delicious food:

1. Scrambled eggs cooked perfectly. It's actually difficult to cook scrambled eggs so that they have that melt-in-your-mouth fluffy texture. Well, this place did it twice!

2. The potatoes were crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside. Great seasonings, too.

3. Hot coffee!

The price is higher than what you would expect for breakfast, but I don't care. It was delicious, convenient (since I stayed at the hotel), and a great start to my day.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Service: Horrible.  wait staff took 30 minutes before they even greeted us (not exaggerating either).  They kept coming to the tables next to us and didn't say hello or acknowledge us.  STRIKE ONE. When we finally got service I asked what beer was a wheat beer and she brought me a dark ale.  STRIKE TWO. Food took forever to come out- when I asked the waitress what was taking so long she told me they only had one cook. STRIKE THREE.
Menu: they were out of three of the main dishes on a tiny menu....seriously? STRIKE FOUR.
Location: Hotel foyer
Food: disappointing.  Not good at all.

Verdict - Consider yourself warned- this place is not worth your time or money.  I asked to speak to the manager when the meal was over, and the waitress told me he went home for the night.
author: Jaclyn O.

description:
The spartan decor is cool, food is above avg, but the sneaky way they charge you for the advanced tip(and don't tell you or show you on the charge slip) and don't volunteer this information misleads you to think you have to add the tip. What a scheme! One ends up with a huge(double) tip. 

We noticed it after asking for the full accounting slip and then removed the added  tip on the one they try to hide. The Estonian lady who served us, accepted our money kept a straight face and it was apparent she was caught red-handed. I guess the Eastern Republic brings there sense of "fraud" and "how to cheat your customer" to America. Welcome to the U.S. we appreciate you bringing your Russian(Eastern Block) mentality with you.

Oh, only four people in restaurant. The chef asked us, as the Estonian server, how we liked the food often. Very little to do I guess. The salmon was not done(Estonian server had a rationalization for this too). 

Given so few people in the restaurant and my guess that others who are good at asking for the full accounting of charges will and have recognized the attempted scheme and will not set foot inside this restaurant again.
author: Ron R.

description:
Like many other reviewers state, Roots is amazingly overpriced and only due to restaurant.com does it bring the entree prices back down to Earth.  The dungeness crab mac n cheese was the sole bright spot as there was quite a bit of crab meat in the average sized plate.  Our waiter, who was a top notch server, recommended the crab mac n cheese as their best entree, especially over the lingcod which he admitted was a bit "flaky" for the recent fish order they received.  

Our other entree was quite disappointing which was a Tripolini Bolognese.  The dish included handmade pasta but considering that the handmade pasta was barely able to wrap around more than a few forkfuls, it was hard to justify the $17 price tag.  I also forgot to add that it was barely cooked and still has that raw pasta aftertaste.

I did like the decor which features roots (to go with the restaurant theme) coming out of the wall and also some neat snake holders for the lamp lights.
author: Albie F.

description:
For all those who never been to Roots and never even heard of it, I'll help you guys out!

The restaurant is inside the Orchard Hotel, which is on Bush, between Grant street in Downtown. 
The restaurant is open for breakfast and dinner only, which makes it kind of weird to enjoy but o wells =T!

Met up with a friend for dinner here and had a the Restaurant.com certificate for $25, which meant to use, we have to spend over $35.  The menu online isn't as accurate as the menus they had for us, so you can take a glance at what they have, but the actual one have a little more.  The menu doesn't  offer much options and it's very simple.  But everything is organic so that's balance things out.  
I ordered the Roots burger and my friend ordered the Tortellini which came out to be $33 bucks...not enough for the certificate!!! 

BUT!! Our server was super nice enough that she said it was fine, and took our orders in...mind you that I always gotten the "look" when I come in with some type of coupon, but she was totally nice about it and gave me absolutely great service!

We were offered poppy-seed bread which was slightly toasted and oil with black pepper...the bread is slightly sweet which was unexpected but was good and warm, so you know its fresh.  Also, nice brown toast marks =).

My burger came and the presentation was nice, i wanted medium well which came out to what I want, however, just a bit dry.  I asked for no tomatoes but it came with it anyways, which wasn't a big deal because I could take it off, but the server saw it and she immediately apologized without me mentioning to her about it, and she seem genuinely sorry about it.  The bun for the burger might be the same as our bread and oil, so it made the burger slightly sweet but it was really good.  The flavor from the cheese and the spicy pickles really blends well with the bun.  The fries were a little salty for my taste, but it was good and crunchy, not soggy and they are not stingy on the fries either!

My friend's order however, was a little disappointing.  Her tortellini arrived with very lightly sauces, but they were full and stuffed with crab as said, however, she said it was very sweet - that the sauce and the pasta case were sweet which made it difficult to eat.  I didn't tried so I can't comment much on it =T.

The decor for this place is very nice and quiet, very calming.  Our server dimmed the lights to match according to the setting, which was nice.  A very small place however, and not a typical restaurant where there's a door to let you know its there.  My silverware and plates were clean and nicely placed.  Our linen for the table were also clean (i know, i just had to add this in case people needed to know!!)  Very simple setting and colors, not meant to amaze you, but it was a great place to catch up on old times with a dear friend.
author: Laurie W.

description:
I bought a Travelzoo voucher and came here with my parents for their anniversary.

The service was great.  Our server was very gracious and offered good suggestions.  She even gave us 2 desserts and one appetizer on the house because of their anniversary.

As for the food, I enjoyed my parents' dishes.  They order the salmon and spare ribs.  The spare ribs were very tender and easy to slice through with just a fork.  I ordered their kobe beef burger, which I thought was only average tasting.  It tasted similar to a Fuddrucker's kobe beef burger.

For dessert, we had an apple cobbler with vanilla ice cream and a pot du creme.  Although the cobbler was waaay too sweet, I enjoyed the crispyness of the apple slices.  It probably needed more dough-y/crust taste too.  The pot-du-creme was also too sweet.  Both desserts were lacking in presentation.

All in all, for someone like my mom who is currently going through chemo, I would come back for their organic foods.  I'll still be on the lookout, however, for something better.
author: Krystal Nina L.

description:
Went here the other night with a Travelzoo deal voucher, and we had an ok but not great experience.  

The cheese and charcuterie platter were ok, but nothing special.  I enjoyed my five-spice braised short ribs, but my wife's pea risotto was below-average.  The risotto was cooked about right, but the dish was severely lacking in flavor.  We NEVER add salt to our food, and we had to do it on a couple of occasions to finish the risotto.  The peas were ok, but didn't add much to the dish.  A little cheese or something like that may have helped.  The dessert, a chocolate / butterscotch pot de creme was tasty, but the texture between the two layers was a bit off -- the bottom layer was too soft, almost flan-like.  

I would probably give the food 3 stars, but I have to deduct a star because the waiter we had was very weird.  He was nice, but said a few things that had us thinking "WTF?!?"  He also didn't really tell us much about the dishes when he brought them (including not describing the charcuterie plate, and not telling us about the kind of red wine we were getting).  

With the voucher, the meal was a good deal, but I don't know if I'll be going back anytime soon.
author: Pilan C.

description:
Came here for dinner w. a friend. Maybe I built up my expectations too much but this place just wasn't that great and certainly didn't match the check we got at the end of the meal. Had the charcuterie plate (decent but nothing exotic or unique) and the crispy salmon (meh).

-Decent customer service 
-It's in a hotel lobby so not much of an ambiance
-The bread they provided after we asked sucked and tasted a bit stale
author: Anya S.

description:
My boyfriend and I were underwhelmed, confused, and uncomfortable. First, it was located in a hotel. Second, no one was there on a Saturday night. Third, the waitress was a weird lady. 

We didn't care to be sitting alone in a restaurant that feels like a hotel lobby on a Saturday night. Its okay for a place to be quiet, but it should at least be romantic which this place is not. 

Not a good experience.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Hubby and I were excited to try Roots because of its best organic restaurant award (SF Weekly).  Sadly, it was a disappointing experience.  

As we walked in, we were shocked that the restaurant was an extension of the Orchard Garden Hotel Lobby.  The decor was bland, clinical even, and the space is not conducive to fine dining.  The soundtrack to our dining experience: hotel guest laughing loudly as they went in and out of the hotel.  We went for an early dinner on Saturday before seeing a play in the city.  At 6pm the restaurant was moderately busy yet the staff seemed a bit flustered.

On a positive note, we had a great Travelzoo deal!  For $45 we had a shared appetizer, two entrees, a cheese course and a glass of wine each.  We started with the prosciutto which was really tasty and the warm green olives were a good addition.  Hubby had the lamb shank and I have to say, it was yummy.  However, my halibut was tasteless and grossly overcooked.  We ended with the cheese plate, which was adequate but the presentation was lacking.  

Overall, Meh!
author: Peta B.

description:
I went back here for dinner with my mom. They have a seasonally menu, and I have to say that this season their menu is pretty lackluster. Nothing on the menu stood out to me so I ended up with a boring kobe beef burger. I will say that my mom really enjoyed her warm olives and beet and pea risotto.

*Check their seasonal menu beforehand!
author: Jenna s.

description:
Busy location but easy to miss this place.

The quality and the freshness of the food was definitely good but my risotto was too salty for my taste.
My husbands beef bourguignon was good and tender but salty too.
My friend thought her pan seared fish was okay and her husband liked his lamb shank
The presentation of the dishes were very nice.
The wine selection was good.

The pastry chef is good making interesting flavors for sorbet and ice cream.
author: Lena N.

description:
Good spot for lunch!  Not sure why the place was empty but lucky for us I guess, b/c we got a table right away.

Portobello-Goat Cheese sandwich was extremely flavorful & the fries were garlicky w/ just the right amount of Parmesan.  Other menu items seemed way too tempting & a definite must have for next time - like the Wild Mushroom Risotto!

Excellent presentation & decor......will definitely go back!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
My girlfriends and I came here for my birthday dinner and decided on the DAT menu.

First of all, it was very empty on a Saturday night. STRANGE.

There was no host to greet us. The bartender, who was very sweet and helpful, eventually took us to our table.

Our waitress was a bit of an odd ball and kind of on the rude side. First words out of her mouth to us, 'You can't use the $50 restaurant.com gift certificate on a DAT dinner. It's one or other'. Uh yeah, thanks for that grand introduction. She just seemed like she didn't really want to be there and so we did our best to ignore her.

Food wise, my steak was wonderful and the mousse for dessert was extremely rich but still pretty good. 

PS - Can I be totally superficial and mention that our waitress had missing teeth. It was ODD. Very extraordinarily normal.

Hmmm...
author: Aim E.

description:
Time: Sunday evening, 7pm

Occasion: Dine About Town (January 2011)
We had a restaurant.com coupon to Roots and decided to use it towards the DAT prix fixe menu in January. 

Location: A little inconspicuous, as it's part of the Orchard Garden Hotel. Close to Chinatown and BART accessible (Montgomery station). 

Service: We were greeted warmly and were seated immediately. I was sick at the time and fell into a coughing fit and the waiter was kind enough to bring me hot water with lemon - and refilled that throughout the night. Our waiter was quite friendly and attentive - he checked in on us during each course and was very helpful in helping us decide what to eat.

Environment: Cozy and intimate - fairly romantic with the soft lighting. Good for dates or for nice dinners with a small group of close friends.

Price: Unfortunately without our restaurant.com coupon and/or the DAT deal, we probably would not have occasion to come back due to the sky-high prices.

Food--
Appetizers: My guy had the fried calimari and I had the salad lyonnaise. Both appetizers were generously proportioned. My salad was quite tasty. They got the dressing en pointe.

Entrees: My guy had the NY strip steak. One star off because it wasn't the most fantastic or memorable steak and he felt that the flavors were rather bland. My pan seared arctic char was delicious - perfectly buttery flaky white fish.

Dessert: Toasted Cardamom Flan with Persimmon Compote and Citrus Lace Cookie. Perfect size to share, delicious.
author: Megan L.

description:
Twice I had my lunch from Roots and twice I got burger! Oh my God, delicious and juicy with amazingly awesome fries! 
You can get it inside out (cheese will be melted inside of the burger)!

Next time I will get the pasta, I promise, if again I will not fell for burger. :)

Very organic, very fresh and tasty!
author: Anelya S.

description:
Came here Saturday for my friend's bday. We had a great time! Great food great service great wine! We had a really good time.
The sous-chef is my good friend's lil bro so we had some nice 'surprises'. Crab mac n cheese would have to be my favorite!
The crabcakes were really good! Nice, lump crab meat. 
We had a bottle of Ventana Sauvignon Blanc, it was yummers. 
They gave us free birthday shots, it was XO Patron coffee liquer, Godiva liquer and chambord & frangelico. 
The service was really wonderful, everyone was so friendly and knowledgeable, especially the bartender, she definitely knew her stuff!
We started with the crab cakes, then salad, truffle fries were yummy too. For entree we had crab mac n cheese, lingcod, and hangar steak.
Can't wait to come back =D
author: Jenny W.

description: The polletta and short ribs is by far one of the most delicious treats on their menu! This is one of the places when I am downtown and want something great for a change that I stop in on a regular basis.
author: Sean H.

description:
I went here about a month ago for Dine About Town. I was also equipped for this fancy meal with a restaurant.com certificate to help with the check only to learn that it is only one or the other. We decided to just order off the menu instead of the prix fixe menu since the items were the same and they did not have a good dessert option for the night.

I loved the ambiance. Roots has a great upscale, bright dining room divided off from the hotel. They had a great menu the night that we went -- I got the mushroom/butternut squash risotto while the bf got a mahi mahi plate. We also got a light citrus salad appetizer with arugula that was fantastic. The quality of food was well above par, however the service did take a while.

You could tell we aren't exactly made for upscale places when my bf asked the waiter whether he should eat his kous kous with the fish or not, but its nice to splurge occasionally and I would definitely choose Roots to do that again sometime.
author: Raina B.

description: This is a good hotel restaurant.  It's very bright and the space feels light and open (there are mirrors flanking both sides of the room, a la Versailles).  The idea of using fresh, local produce where possible is commendable.  Our server was very friendly and provided excellent recommendations.  The steak was well prepared, and the risotto had a nice flavor although it was lacking somewhat in richness.
author: Vijay N.

description: My gf had a coupon for Roots so we decided to check it out. Roots boasts organic, locally sustainable food in one of the most eco-friendly hotels in San Francisco. Inside of the Orchard Garden hotel, we arrived and we were the only patrons other than the guests checking in/out. We grabbed a table and were told that they were no longer accepting the coupons (weird) and we could leave if we wanted. However the bartender told us that the food was really good and to give it a try. Fortunately, it was still happy hour so we ordered a few glasses of wine and decided to stay. We ordered the truffle fries, the risotto and the spare ribs. Everything was amazing. The fries were crispy and so addicting. It was hard to stop picking at. The spare ribs were amazing. I have never had anything like it. The meat was moist, flavorful and soft. It was the best dish of the night. We polished off the whole plate before diving into the risotto. The second best dish of the night was the angel food cake w/ berries dessert. The cake was so fluffy, the whipped cream was fresh and light and the berries threw in a nice kick. We were so shocked that an empty restaurant could dish out such great food. Unfortunately with the location being near Union Square and in a hotel, its hard for people passing by to notice it. I highly recommend this restaurant. It was so good I took my boyfriend here the following week.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Meh. Meeeeeeeeeehhhhh.

I actually had high expectations for Roots. I thought people were just being snooty and giving them a 3 star rating because, well, it makes you feel cool to judge.

I was wrong. For me this was actually a 2.5 star restaurant... AHAHAH IM SNOOTIER THAN THE REST OF YOU. but because i liked the server/bartender (the only server they have on a Thursday night), I'll bump em up half a star. 

The ambience is underwhelming. And when I say underwhelming I mean plain. and when i say i mean plain, I mean bland. I felt like I was in the lobby of a very average hotel, rather than a nice restaurant. They have to work on giving the restaurant it's own feel. Though Roots had a few cool pieces, (the decor behind the bar was nice) taking everything into account, this is people just happen to stop by tto eat at, not a place people would plan to go too at these prices.

That being said I had the $50 restaurant.com coupon, meaning we'd have to at least spend $100 dollares to make it worthwhile. I thought we were going to be able to eat a FEAST, or at least be very full. That did not happen to be the case.

We started off with a drink... which was well made (sorry don't remember.)

Followed that up with the soup. It was some sort of mushroom vegan soup which I thought was decent. I'd give it a B.

Now for the entrees (3 of which we split): 

dungeness crab mac & Cheese: This was the winner in my book. I thought it was pretty good. I am a mac & cheese lover, and when you cook it just right with the edges all crispy, you got yourself a winner. I'd give the mac & cheese.. Grade: A.

scallops : eek, aah, why. why did you ruin scallops. Poorly cooked little things. Not only did they kill you, but they decided to cook you as if you were a second rate dish, but still charge first rate prices. Poor little things. I didnt enjoy this dish very much at all, flavor or texture. BOO for you.  Grade : C-

flat iron steak - eh. i think i'd have trouble judging flat iron steak anywhere. frankly it was decent. but Flat Iron is such a cheap cut of meat. There was just absolutely nothing special about it. It's mediocrity did not warrant a near $30 pricemark. Grade: B-

Dessert : Chocolatini: decent

pear mousse: have you ever licked a pear and eaten a cupful of whipped cream before? that's pretty much what this pear mousse is. the pear flavor was so delicate as to almost not being present. Grade: D+

i liked the waiter though... so i'll be nice
author: Garrett W.

description: My friend and I met in SFO for a girl's weekend.  We had a great diner Friday but it was heavy on the beef and prok, so our criteria for a Saturday evening dinner in the city were local, fresh, vegetable based foods in a trendy, cool environment. The Roots sounded great-sustainable? Awesome. We walk in and I said to the doorman, incredulously, is THAT this restaurant?" The super-brightly lit, EMPTY (save for one elderly couple), cafeteria-like setting with BAD muzak playing was NOT what we'd had in mind. One look at each other and my friend and I started cracking up. It was so bad it was comical.
author: Julie G.

description:
We went here because we were staying in the Orchard hotel, which itself is a fabulous place.  Its menu changes often, as you would expect from a hotel-embedded eatery, so keep a close eye on it.  
The food was delicious, their soup of the day was spot-on, and their wine list is reasonable.  
It lacked a little variety and creativity and didn't have the "fine dining feel" that went with its fine dining look. Overall very good, should upscale it a little further though
author: Domenic M.

description:
You know what the food here reminds me of? The contestants on Top Chef who are probably technically decent but get eliminated early because they make inexplicably bad choices.  Roots is trying really hard to be a fancy hotel restaurant. It's got the white table cloths and the stuffy decor, but it has no idea what it is doing.

Why would you serve deliciously warm bread with cold, hard, mismatched packets of butter?  Why would you serve seared scallops in a bowl of broth, and furthermore, not give the diner a spoon or any bread to soak it up with?  The whole evening featured incongruities like these. 

And then it became hilarious.  The waiter accidentally spilled the (aforementioned why-does-it-even-exist) broth all over our table, which prompted him to exclaim, "Oh shit!!"  Oops.  After cleaning it up, he goes into the kitchen (which we were seated near) and, still within earshot, says, "You will NOT believe what I just did..."  Facepalm.

To make up for this, he gives us a free dessert.  Whoever plated the dessert was trying so hard to be artistic and sophisticated, but the dessert itself looked and tasted like Jell-o chocolate pudding.

As with the Top Chef contestants, there is potential here.  The scallops were very well-seasoned.  The smoked trout salad was almost great, but had weird proportions and sizes of ingredients.  Conceptually, I could almost see what they were trying to do.  But the execution was totally lacking.  If the meal had been any more expensive than it was, I probably would have been upset.  But as it was, it was just an unexpectedly amusing dining experience I hope not to repeat again.
author: Leslie L.

description:
The atmosphere is described as "romantic" but really it's a lovely restaurant for small groups. I came here with two of my gal pals and we had a wonderful dinner thanks to a very knowledgeable waitress.

Most memorable dishes I had at Roots is their complimentary dinner bread and bread pudding. UHhhhh I'm still dreaming about the dinner bread a year later. Nice crispy crust, but fluffy and airy on the inside. The bread pudding was made from had croissants left over from the day before, so the chef decided to make bread pudding... God bless him! 

I don't remember much of the entrees themselves, lemony risotto and a fish dish (which i remember was a tad too salty. I think that's an American thing, I always find the fish too salty.) Overall I was satisfied and would definitely come back again. I promise to write a more prompt review next time!
author: Lynn T.

description:
I get such odd, mixed vibes from dining at this place. I've been twice now; both times with a friend who lives nearby and loves the place.

So, the food itself is good. Nice variety of dishes, if not a bit limited.

It's very bright inside. My friend loves this; I don't. For some reason, it brings back memories of late-night dining at Perkin's in high school. 

It's a bit overpriced, IMO. Only one glass of white wine under $10; and cocktails are $12. Sure, it's a hotel in Union Square, so maybe that's the norm, but for someone who typically dines in Mission/Hayes/Tendernob/SoMa, drink prices (food also) seems a bit steep.

Service is slow at times; but friendly. I think we caught it on a particularly busy night. One server (who didn't have our table initially) ended up being particularly friendly (in a good way), to the point our group invited him out for drinks later. 

I'm giving it 2.5 stars for the overall experience, rounding up because we received a free caesar salad which was accidentally prepared as an extra. gracias! =)

So what could be done to make it better? Dim the lights, add some music for ambiance (so I don't have to hear the conversations from every other table in the place), lower the prices a bit, keep the food as is. And maybe play up the green-ness of the hotel/building, I had no idea, but other reviews are mentioning it.
author: Daniel P.

description: Roots is closed temporarily for dinner (as of May 22, 2014)  but will be back in business soon -- is only serving breakfast now.  Best to call before.
author: Janice A.

description:
Good: Nice fancy place to eat.  The waiter was very friendly.  Food was fantastic.

Bad: Pricey.  Food took way too long to come for some reason.
author: David L.

description:
We also went for Thanksgiving dinner and were sorely disappointed. It started out fine, we ordered promptly, the munu was prix fixe, which we knew going in. there was a choice of soup or salad, a choice of 2 entrees, assorted side dishes and a choice of desserts. None of us chose the wine pairings. We ordered two of the tamale pies and three of the turkey dinners. We were told that the tamale pies did not come with the side dishes no matter how it looked on the menu, fine. 

The soup and salad were quite tasty, but it went downhill from there.  The tamale pies were inedible, the adult and child both took only one bite of theirs before determining that. The waitress never came to the table to ask us how our meals were the entire time we were eating, in fact when she cleared the plates it was obvious that  not more than one bite was taken from either of the tamale pies but she cleared them with no comments. 

Three of us had the turkey dinner which was mediocre at best, the turkey breast appeared to be from a boneless a rolled breast because I really am not familiar with any part of the bird shaped like what I was served.  I swear I got 6 green beans and about 4 cranberries.  Then our dessert was served, which was very good, a creme brulee and a bread pudding. 

Finally when the waitress brought the check she asked how everything was, which was when we told her of our dissappointment.. I was a little more than perturbed because this dinner was not cheap and we were talking about stopping someplace on the way home to get something for the two who did not eat. 

We asked to see the menu again and pointed out that it appeared that the side dishes were to be served with both entrees and the two with the tamale pies were finally served them, which seemed to satisfy their hunger finally. 

We were offered no apologies, no adjustment on the bill, nothing. All I got out of the experience was a good restaurant horror story to tell my friends back in Florida.
author: Gail P.

description:
Delicious. I recommend the Dungeness crab mac and cheese and the flatiron steak sandwich, medium rare.

The downside? Slow.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Yup, like most other Yelpers, I came upon this place thanks to a $2 for $25 resturant.com gift cert. First of all, how the heck does it take 10 minutes to get water and 30 to get french fries? Do I want to look at people checking and and luggage carts going by while I eat my overpriced meal? Of course not!

So I got, based on Yelp recommendations, the Crab Mac and Cheese. There were maybe 2 bits of crab in there and the rest of it was just fishy-tasting Mac and Cheese...for $13.

My GF got some fish dish that was super bland. For $22.

The happy hour special was pretty good though. A martini and a free appetizer (hence the 30 minute French Fries) for $12.

Basically, if I'm paying that much chedda, with or without a gift cert, I either want amazing food or an incredible atmosphere. I got neither, so enjoy my 2 star rating roots.
author: Greg G.

description:
This is one of my new favorite places in SF! Here are my reasons:
1. They take restaurant.com coupons so a $100 meal can be cut down by $50!
2.  They give very generous portions so no one is left hungry!
3.  The food is high-quality and very good tasting! For appetizers, we had the cheese appetizer and black bean soup; for entrees we had the scallops and the flank steak; and for dessert we had a spiced pumpkin creme brulee.  Everything was very good.
4. Service, though it started off slow, was excellent!
5. Ambiance: small restaurant set at the entrance of the Orchard Garden Hotel... very nice, bright restaurant.  And they even have a "green" take on food! 

I will be back... next month... when I can use another restaurant.com certificate!

P.S... they have happy hour everyday (weekends too!) from 4-7; buy an alcoholic drink and get a free appetizer! That makes me very happy!
author: Grace M.

description:
Roots is a terrific little restaurant burrowed in the lobby of a hotel in Nob Hill area. It looks like I'm not the only Yelper that happened upon Roots via a Restaurant.com gift certificate. It's a bit pricey without the $50 certificate...but with the certificate, the prices are just right. We enjoyed coffee and lattes brewed with organically grown beans, ripe and flavorful fruit bowls, and heartily prepared brunch dishes like breakfast burritos and traditional eggs dishes. One touch that we all enjoyed was the sauteed Portobello mushrooms. They were absolutely delicious and tandem with the breakfast burritos. 

The service was very friendly and attentive to our requests. We also liked the intimate and secluded feel during our Sunday morning brunch. 

The only downsides to Roots are that they have a very limited menu and their regular prices are pretty high for the dishes offered.

I'd highly recommend visiting Roots with a few friends and the $50 Restaurant.com coupon in hand.
author: John Z.

description:
Bland decor and food is below average when compared to other restaurants within the same price range.  

It was a slow Saturday night with 2 servers.  I liked their service, the girl occasionally came around to make sure everything was ok.  The duck breast had the perfect pink with a nice sweet orangy sauce drizzled on top.  But the flat noodles served on the side was pretty nasty.  The sesame flavor was way too strong.  

The goat cheese and cranberry salad was ok, nothingyou can't make at home.  The truffle fries was delicious, and huge portion!  We shared it as an appetizer.  

Came here for the DAT special.  There's nothing else I liked on the regular menu, so I won't be back.
author: Tadaa T.

description:
Fresh, all American dishes with an organic flair.  And Anchor Steam beers.  Hollerrrrrrrrrrrrrrr.

The restaurant is in a pretty sterile environment of a hotel lobby...but once you sit down and try to forget that people may be walking around checking in to their room, it's all quite easy to take in.  The bathrooms are gorgeous to top it all off, and who doesn't like a well-lit bathroom to check themselves out in??

Each person at the table managed to choose a different dish from the menu which never usually happens - bigger sample size, cha CHING!  My game hen was delicious, with a perfect balance of flavor accomplished by layering with sweet potatoes.  Other memorable dishes were the duck salad with an asian twist and the steak with parsnips.  Mmmm...parsnips.

Great dishes, attentive staff (albeit from socal, snore) and I think there's some type of saver coupon which allows you to buy gift certificates for less than the amount of the coupon itself.  Call us perpetual student-minded people...
author: Grace L.

description:
I went here for a festive work lunch.  The atmosphere is lovely -- light, airy, and elegant.  Our server was friendly yet casual.

The menu was well-written, as everything looked delicious!  There was a nice selection of creative salads, sandwiches, and entrees.  People definitely enjoyed their meals, and I enjoyed knowing that  I was eating "green."

I have to ding them a star for slooooooooooow pacing.  When you're paying top-dollar for a lunch *and* you're the only people in the restaurant, it shouldn't take that long between courses.  (This would probably be less of an issue if it was a meal with friends and/or drinks were involved.)

Still, I will keep Roots in mind for future upscale lunch opportunities.  Or maybe even dinner.
author: Andi T.

description:
I definitely won't call this place cheap.....but their happy hour has free appetizers from 4-7 w/ the purchase of a mixed cocktail or a glass of wine. 

I have some time to kill (in between a co-worker's art opening and a Yelp event at the Exit Theater) so I decide to take the bait. of free appetizers. First thing that I notice is the place is real clean and the fountian in the front is cool. Well lit establishment and airy. The bartenders are friendly and will make small talk. The cocktails are $12 each, but they are pretty strong. I mean, I was buzzed from the glasses of wine at the art opening....but the cocktail was a good finisher. I ordered the french fries w/ garlic, parmesean and truffle butter. I expected a small bowl of foofy fries....and out comes a real good bowl of substatial spuds! Yes they were good! My suggestion would be to have maybe 2-3 people and have a cocktail each and order different apetizers and share it family style..... $12 for a dinner at that nice of an establishment isn't bad at all.
author: Angelo F.

description:
Take the "Roots" out of roots and call it something else, because this restaurant does not know anything about being down to earth or  eco-friendly. I went to "Roots" for lunch today, expecting stellar service and earthy selection, and got nothing short of a ho-hum meal from an unclear menu. 

 All I can say is Vegetarians and Vegans beware! My vegetarian friend had to learn the hard way that they put diced up little anchovies in the olive dipping spread. Not only did they have hidden anchovies, but a hidden menu. Apparently, they think that customers like to be surprised when their food arrives. I don't know about you, but I like to know what I'm getting, and when my chicken sandwich was brought out dripping with mayo, and yes the anchovies, I was not happy. How hard would it have been to write on the menu that the sandwich came with mayo and an olive spread with anchovies on it? 

 Maybe Roots should check their eco-conscience and be more considerate of those with dietary restrictions. I'm not a vegan or a Vegetarian, but I like to know what I'm getting. There are too many mysteries in life already.
author: Michelle K.

description:
In reading some reviews for this place, there are things that I agree with, the food is wonderful and there are not enough people there.

I went here for lunch several weeks ago. I was hungry, but not starved and my lunch date is rarely hungry, so we decided to share a few dishes. 

I started with a lemonade. Some places I go to saw fresh or organic or something that is clearly a lie upon being served, as I know that lemons are not pink. There lemonade was fresh, organic, YELLOW, and everything that makes a lemonade wonderful.

The first course was macaroni and cheese with crab, which was wonderful. Though, as it sounds, it is rich! I could have just shared this and have been full. If you read more of my reviews, I eat a lot.

By the time the second course arrived, the sirloin strip sandwich and a side of parmesan and truffle sprinkled french fries, we were both full. I ate some french fries, but we mutually decided to take our sandwich to go. After trying only a bite, I could tell it was wonderful. If was not like a lowbrow steak sandwich, it was prime sirloin, cooked perfectly, with little fat.

I highly suggest this place. It surprises me that more people do not go here. The lighting isn't the best, but the seats are comfortable and the food is DELICIOUS!
author: Christopher W.

description:
It's too bad the decor is so bland because the food was absolutely delicious.  The room looks like a boring hotel dining room, which I think only serves to deter customers and which is a shame since the food is great.

We ate breakfast here twice: egg white omelette with swiss, asparagus and spinach, pancakes, eggs, bacon - all of it hot, fresh, and light. 

We ordered room service for dinner: burger, some fancy pasta with meat sauce (sorry, I can't remember the name), vegan corn soup, arugula salad.  It was actually the best food I had during my five day stay in SF.  

I appreciate that it's all organic, local, sustainable, etc., and that it is delicious (most important!)
author: Kathy K.

description:
So I'm hesitant to review this restaurant.  I love the food here.  I love the free appetizer with each drink you order.  (That's right, order 3 drinks get 3 appetizers!)  And they're really good appetizers - beef carpaccio, truffle-parmesan fries, etc.  I love the people who work here.  And I especially LOVE the roof top deck that nobody uses.  There's no service up there, but you can buy a bottle of wine and bring it up with you.  It's brilliant at night with all of the city lights.  

So, the reason for my hesitancy?  I don't want you to go there.  I want to keep this one all to myself.  But I really like the folks who run this place and want them to do well.  So there, I'll throw myself under the bus.  Good thing my reviews aren't witty enough for the "review of the day," because then you'll all show up.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Who knew? Fresh ingredients, knowledgeable service, tasty food... in a hotel lobby restaurant. Tucked away in the new Orchard Garden Hotel, Roots offers a well executed dining experience that's green all over. (Well, except for the totally monochrome decor.) The cheese plate we ordered was an excellent value, and the risotto entree was delicious. The scallop ceviche, while flavorful, didn't quite live up.

As much as I did enjoy my meal at Roots, the way the place is set up made it hard for me to ignore that I was basically eating dinner in a lobby. Try to get seats not by the relatively unshielded walkway and obtrusive fluorescent lighting... surprising that more wasn't done to separate what's a cozy dining area from hotel guests walking to and from the elevator.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Somewhat pricey but that's what you get for being "green."

Cool factor: the entire place is composed of sustainable products.

Delicious food, decent wine selection, and surprising good drinks.
author: Francis M.

description:
Never heard about the place until I went there for lunch - it's located at the new environmental-friendly hotel, Orchard Garden Hotel. 

THE GOOD | The food was good and prices were reasonable. The theme is that most stuff here is all-organic which is nice. Ideal for a business lunch setting since it's relatively quiet - but then again, we met at 11AM

THE BAD | Roots seems like a misnomer. I was recommended the place because I had a preference for salads, but ended up ordering a sandwich and fries (garlic fries with truffle oil = YUM!) and my colleague ordered a hamburger  since their selection of greens was rather limited. The setting seems a bit off - the restaurant is an open-space area so upon entering, it wasn't clear where the restaurant was. At the same time, we arrived when a tour of the hotel was taking place right in the middle of restaurant to show the eco-friendly features of the hotel.

Overall, I didn't hate the place but it wasn't as memorable as I would have liked it to be. I'd go back out of convenience but wouldn't make too much of an effort on my own.
author: buggy b.

description:
Hosted my boss and several colleagues from out of town here for a lovely meal. They have a nice private alcove toward the back of the dining room that is perfect for a group of 8-10.  Service was very accommodating and friendly, if a bit unrefined. The daily Farmers Market soup was an asparagas puree that was outstanding. Main courses of risotto and the organic chicken were fabulous. The warm chocolate tart was the perfect ending.  The manager and chef here are top-notch and anxious to fulfill your special requests. A great place to do something special and to leave feeling special.

UPDATE: A recent visit pre-theater left us again happy and satisfied. After drinks and nibbles at the bar, we sat down at 7pm in the dining room and told our dear waitress Lynn we had tickets for an 8pm show.  She ensured we could enjoy most of a fine bottle of  French Rose and 2 killer entrees without missing the curtain. The pork chop is incredibly tasty and moist, having brined for 48 hours. My beau had the steak and declared it the best he has had out in SF in quite a while.   We do hope more folks discover this gem, but not too many so that we have to fight for a seat at the small bar.
author: Tom C.

description:
I figured that this place would be packed on a Friday night, so I called ahead and made a reservation. It was kind of embarrassing to show up and be the third table there.

To the servers' credits, we were seated immediately (one could only hope) - but in the darkest corner of this hotel lobby, behind a wall. Benefit of the doubt tells me they really wanted to give me and my late party some privacy. That or they didn't want anyone to see me in my hooded sweatshirt and jeans. Damn it, I was wearing decent shoes.

The real reason why I came here was because I had a gift certificate. Our waitress insisted it was called a coupon. Now that we were deemed cheap, we felt the need to redeem ourselves with some cocktails. The lady had an interesting blend of vodka and Odwalla (what?) and I said, why not, and went for the XOChocolatini or whatever it was called (shut up). I'm really not sure what you're supposed to pair that one up with. The whole cocktail menu was just bizarre.

The best way to class up some french fries, other than the requisite Kraft parmesan, is to drizzle it with truffle oil. We fell for it, naturally.

I wasn't sure what I wanted, so I asked if I should go for the scallop/mussel dish or the lamb. She said she'd surprise me (and after that drink, I couldn't have cared less). The scallops arrived, as did the tamale pie with Mexican truffles, the crab mac and cheese, and the smoked trout salad. It really looked great when it arrived.

Unfortunately, the tastes were a little disappointing. There were but a few slivers of trout in the salad (around 2), the mac and cheese was nothing really to write home about (especially at $13), and the tamale pie was apparently full of rich flavors that clashed into blandness. Our waitress insisted you didn't need to be a vegetarian to enjoy this wonderful dish, but the vegetarian at our table found it hard to swallow.

The scallops and mussels had a lot of flavor to them, but I swear the cook dropped a can of Morton's in there. I'm sure the little girl with the umbrella was screaming GET ME OUT OF HERE, and all I could wonder was if it was iodine free or not. The chocolate cocktail turned out to be a blessing in disguise.

And the decor? Beige, beige, beige, that was the color of everything. I think everything just blended into each other. I understand the organic, earthy inspiration behind it but... The greatest distraction was the green Exit sign to the bathroom (which is spotless, by the way, but be forewarned that the men's lock doesn't work very well. I just didn't bother to lock it. Heyyyy.).

None of us were in the mood for dessert. For $100, we were hoping for a little something more. But we pretty much got what was on the wall - just a lot of... well, beige.
author: Carl W.

description:
Love that it's organic although I never really care too much for that kind of thing.

Went there for a couple lunch dates with some gfs because we use restaurant.com gift certificates.  The food is still pretty pricey though.

Although service takes forever, the food is really well made and delicious.  Definitely LOVE their burger, my two gfs loved them too.  They're huge so it's great to pack half for dinner and the fries are... well fries.  I also really enjoyed the risotto but my gf said she'd had better. Slightly remember really enjoying their dessert too.

Definitely worth it if you have the gift certificate.  I dunno if I'd come here and pay full price though.

Cons: Pricey & long wait for food

Pros: Delicious food (of what I've tried), friendly service, usually empty for lunch (I guess it's b/c it's in a hotel), quiet, really cute restaurant, organic, and on Restaurant.com!!
author: Kay R.

description: What can one say, great food, great service, beautifully presented, coupled with fine choices for wine pairings. We enjoyed our V-day dinner: amuse bouche, antipasto, salad, steaks, meyer lemon dessert, wine couplings, and of course, a latte too boot. Lynn and Felicia were of great help. Reasonably priced as I had my Restaurant.com gift certificate I got the same day w/ the discount code... ;)
author: Johnson H.

description:
Have to say the restaurant setting was very nice.  The menu was very appealing when I looked at it online.  But...

I would have to agree with Andi T.  The service ended up being very slow.  We were the third table at the restaurant, after the other two tables were either being served or finishing their meal.  There is no excuse for slow service especially when there is no one at the restaurant!  Our waiter took a while to refill our waters and my beverage.  I noticed he finally had the jar of water in hand, but then saw that another table was finished with their meal.  Even though he had been heading over in our direction, he decided to clear the other table first.

Additionally, the food didn't turn out as I had expected.  The fries were good for the first few--then they became overly parmesan cheesey.  Two of us ordered the flat iron steak sandwich which came with a mini arugula greens mixture.  This was ridiculously salty.  Another person specifically requested no mayonnaise on her sandwich and the waiter said he could accommodate this, but her sandwich still came out with mayo.

The only good thing was that we had a $25 restaurant.com certificate to apply to our bill which made the meal quite cheaper.  I will also say that the manager did a good job to make sure we had everything we needed and also cleared the table quickly.  However, I don't think I will be coming back just because the food was pricey and although it sounded good from the menu, very normal and didn't meet my expectations.
author: Christopher W.

description:
The Orchard Garden Hotel is the only LEED certified hotel in the city.  That already makes it a superstar in my mind and I haven't even been in the rooms.   

I did, however, enjoy a lovely meal at Roots, the restaurant in the Hotel Lobby.  The food and the wines are sustainable, organic and/or biodynamic.  Both have a lot of variety and there is at least one vegan item in each course selection.  They are also happy to make modifications to menu items to suit your dietary restrictions/pallet.  

To start I had the Grilled Tofu- Bloomsdale spinach- with hazelnuts and dried cranberries.  The marinade on the tofu was delicious and was a nice combo with the nuts and cranberries.  Next came the saffron risotto with broccoli rabe, pine nuts, currants & chile flakes.  It was just the right amount of spice and very tasty and filling.  My friend had the Arugula Salad with Humbolt Fog blue cheese, strawberries and candied pecans followed by the smoked pork loin with couscous peas,  rhubarb and almonds.  She, too was quite impressed.

Neither of us had room for dessert.   It was a lot of food and worth every penny!

The weird thing was that this place was nearly empty at 7:30 on a Friday night.  What's up with that?  The only thing I did not like is that the restaurant is right off the hotel lobby and not separated at all so you do get a lot of noise from the front, but I'm totally willing to overlook that as the food, the cocktails and the service more than make up for it.

So... check it out.  Spread the word.  Don't let Roots be another casualty of the San Francisco restaurant glut...  we want this one to stick around, trust me!
author: LeSLiE W.

description:
Nice, nice, nice place

Nice and clean atmosphere. (Could have more personality, oh well...)
Quiet atmosphere in the middle of busy area offers nice reprieve.

Super nice service. Chef Russel is no Gordon Ramsey: personable and subdued. Make you feel part of the family. The staff brings warmth to the place.

Nice green twist: as much organic, sustainable, farmer's market choice ingredients as possible, showcased by simple recipes. Great organic sustainable wine list too.

Also part of a nice hotel, first with a green twist in San Francisco.
author: Elsa T.

description: I have a travelzoo voucher and am wondering if I should even try Roots. The bad experiences likely is because the restaurant is closing at the end of June, and they've reportedly already let go of the staff. So, most people working there likely are temp, so there's no point in offering good service. Details on closure: http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2011/06/17/daffodil-and-roots-closing-at-the-end-of-the-month/
author: rosanna c.

description:
Continuing the fashionista meets recessionista vein of trying new restaurants, hubby and I dined last night at Roots.  I had come armed with a  Restaurants.com $25 cerficate.  Being hungry after a big 20 mile bike ride, we opted for an early dinner.  We were the only ones in the restaurant at 6:30 pm, but they told us that we could start with the happy hour deal (as enumerated by the many other Yelp reveiws).

As soon as we took our seats, the restaurant started filling up.  The bar was crowded with a group of Europeans opening bottle after bottle of champagne.  Eventually, there were 8 tables seated in the dining area.  iThis is much different than what was expected based upon the reviews.  

Menu was extremely limited - half dozen appetizer options, five entrees, three desserts.  I'm not surprised since it seems that no one really eats here- would be a waste to have more food than necessary.  We had the truffle french fries, arugula with strawberry salad, asparagus risotto, and the diver scallops with PEI mussels.

There was a giant pork chop that others ordered that looked delicious.

Our food came out promptly and was very good.  I had a mussel or two that tasted "odd", but they were plump and not over cooked.  The scallops were large and perfectly seared.  The risotta was creamy and flavorful.

Our bill was a deal-2 free apps with 3 drinks during HH + coupon  + tax + ttip all for less than $75.  Not bad for a beautiful setting and attentive staff.

To address the slow kitchen complaints:  I did see the entrees for the couple who was seated shortly after us arrive as we signed our check.   
Everyone else seemed to get prompt delivery.

Will I be back the next time I come to S.F?  Maybe.
author: E T.

description:
This restaurant is right next to the gates of Chinatown and inside the Garden Orchard Hotel. I went here with a group of 6 people who were ready for some good food and fun.

The ambiance here is neither fun, nor sexy. It's more romantic, but even then I would have to recommend other places. The decor is white and a bit sterile, but not in the 2002 minimalist way. It's more of a classier Miami Vice. The lighting isn't quite right either. There is a bar in the front, but I didn't actually go to it or order a drink.

What we ate: Parmesan fries - these were delicious! Wild Mushroom Risotto - somehow this didn't work for me and I usually love risotto. The short ribs ragout more sweet than savory so didn't work well either. My friend had an undercooked steak. sent back to be cooked a bit longer.

For a Sat night, there was only one other table with patrons from 7-9. I'm not sure who I find this place suitable for. It also turned out that the chef was actually our waiter. Something tells me this place is going to be replaced and with good reason.
author: Neelima D.

description:
My wife and I were in San Francisco last Saturday night and found this place on Yelp.  We arrived at prime time, and found only one other couple there, just finishing their dinner.   That was scary, but we stayed anyway as we were hungry and were encouraged by some of the reviews on Yelp.   

We were pleasantly surprised (even when no one else arrived the whole time we were there).   My Chinese Short Ribs dish was excellent, my wife combined the Ginger Chicken Lollipops appetizer with a Daikon Romaine salad and loved both.   A very tasty Chocolate/Butterscotch Pot de Creme dessert topped it off.

Our server, Jason, was quite friendly and we chatted quite a bit (as he was obviously not very busy).    Apparently, the owners do not market or publicize the restaurant at all anymore.   We don't understand their 'strategy', as the food here was quite tasty.   Some of the decor choices were odd, but we had a good laugh about that and we were there to eat anyway.

Worth giving a try!
author: Bodhi S.

description:
I had high hopes for this place but it turned out to be one of the worst dinners I've ever had.  2 star is generous and only because the wine (red zin) and appetizer (crab mac and cheese) was good.  I went there with my bf and friend and was excited about this organic foodie experience.  For starters we had the arugula and goat cheese salad, pretty standard, nothing to rave about.  The crab mac and cheese was rich and generous portion, very good but you have to share to have room for entrees.  although now I think that was a bad idea since the entrees were downright horrible.

My friend ordered the flatiron steak medium rare, my bf and I ordered the scallops with mussels.  The steak came out medium and overly salted.  The scallops were so salty thats all I tasted, it was like if it was dipped in salt, seared and dipped in salt again.   We sent our entrees back and ordered the panfried sole with roasted red pepper and my friend got the mushroom risotto.  The sole came out tasteless and very greasy, it was also 2 very small filets both could have fit on my palm easily.  I took one bite and just couldn't allow myself to eat something so greasy and disgusting.  The risotto my friend had was watery and bland, I tried it and it tasted more like porridge with large chewy vegetable leaves that were hard to swallow.  The bill came to be $85 and I must say it was the most unsatisfactory $85 we've ever spend.  I apologized profusely to my friend for inviting him to try such a tasteless dinner.  We will not be back!
author: Yue L.

description: I've eaten here several times and each time I'm newly impressed. Innovative food prepared with the freshest ingredients. Most memorable dishes were the Japanese Caesar salad w/black sesame seeds and the short ribs w/polenta. The only thing that stopped me from giving 5 stars is that the atmosphere could stand some improvement. It's hard to forget that you're pretty much dining in the midst of a hotel lobby.
author: Marci A.

description:
Decent enough organic food restaurant.
Nothing particularly special... except for the croissant bread pudding.
Holy ****. Maybe the most awesome, decadent dessert ever!
We split it between 2 people. It's so rich, is probably best split among 4 people. It was life-altering.
author: David C.

description:
We discovered Roots at the Dine About Town kick-off event in the Macy's Cellar earlier this week. We decided to try happy hour since it isn't far from my work.  We got there at six and I was shocked to see maybe 4 people there. We told the bartender that we were there for happy hour and then he said he could put a few tables together for us...then he went behind the bar and we stood around thinking he would eventually put the tables together. Then we talked to the server about being seated so she put the tables together and then pulled out the dinner menus for us. 

Since we were there because of Dine About Town, we asked to see that menu too. She brought out more menus. Since we were there for happy hour, we asked about that too..pretty soon there were 15 paper menus on our table plus one paper wine menu for the five of us. We read on Yelp earlier that you can order a free appetizer with the purchase of a cocktail so we did that. The fries with truffle oil were amazing. Two of the guys with us were doing a "Biggest Loser" competition at work so they had to show restraint...more for us girls! Also, the shrimp and grits were really good, loaded with butter, but we tried not to think about that. The cocktails were good too.

The service was extremely slow, especially noticeable because there were not many patrons there with us, but to be fair there was only the bartender and the server. A busser came in around 7 to help out but it did not speed things up by much. The server thought we had come for dinner, hence all the menus, so she felt a bit duped (and didn't hide it well) when we told her we came for happy hour. But seriously, if you share the free appetizers and have one drink, there is enough for a good meal.

Overall I had a good time. I will be going back, but also will be making it clear to the server that I'm there for the happy hour specials only.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
It almost gets 5 stars based on the food and service alone.  Had a fully enjoyable experience on Friday night.  The "small" cheese platter is delicious and larger than you think, would suffice for a party of 2 to 4, depending on how much you love cheese.  For my gf and me, there was extra to bring home, and we love cheese.  If ordering individually from the cheese menu, I recommend the Truffle Tremor goat cheese from Arcata.  The smoked trout starter on endives, with a smooth horseradish sauce, and apples tossed in, is light, crispy, and tasty without being too fishy.  The wild mushroom tamale pie gets creativity points to be sure, and very symbolic of California cultures: they get their wild mushrooms from post-hippie mushroom hunters, ladle them with a Mexican tamale sauce, other vegetables, and it arrives with a cornmeal lattice baked on top.  

The waiter we had was exceptionally personable and attentive but not interrupting.  Could not have asked for better service and I hope she knows it.  

The ambiance is the only aspect that misses 5 stars. It is a hotel restaurant, though the fountain in the lobby is beautiful.  The restaurant was literally empty when I arrived at 7:30pm on a Friday night, and only a few parties arrived thereafter.  So, if you are looking for a quiet place, where you are sure to get personal attention and cuisine made to order, I highly recommend it.  

P.S. Pricey, but you can get a good discount at www.restaurant.com
author: Sierra M.

description:
One of the worst restaurants I've been to.  We went here on a Friday night because of a $50 certificate from Restaurant.com.  The service was fine but the food was not.

We order the mac-n-cheese which was their signature apertizer but heck where was the cheese?!!!! It was dry and tasteless.  The menu for entre was limited to only 4 options so there wasn't that much to begin in. Everything was salty, from the pork chop to the scallops to the vegertarian dish.

The place was EMPTY! It could be because people never come back!

Throughout dinner, this short manager kept on interupting us.  Granted that he's accomodating but every freeking 15 minutes, come on!  I was with a group of gfs and we were talking about engagement rings and he rudely interupted our conversation and asked all these personal questions about the ring..wtf? 

The bill still came out pretty hefty with the $50 certificate.  We were pretty upset because the food was just not worth the $ that we paid.
author: TU B.

description:
Roots was okay. That is pretty much the best way to describe my dining experience there. We went because we had a gift certificate, and I was excited to try all organic food. But, the food wasn't all that great. It was kind of boring and bland. There weren't many people there, yet the waitress still took forever to notice when we needed something. If the restaurant were at least a good value, that may have helped, but I thought it was expensive for the quality of food they put out.

I would not go back to this place. When there are so many great restaurants in the city, this place just does not measure up. I do have to say that the wine I ordered (Sav Blanc, I think) was delicious, and the bartender (slash host?) was awesome. He seated us, kept our water full, cleared our plates, etc, and was so nice. I would say the bartender was the best part of that meal, and is the only reason I gave Roots 3 stars instead of 2. But overall, it just didn't do it for me.
author: Bridgette A.

description: Despite the fact that I was totally hungover from sunday brunch at LIME and Buddha Sushi (hey it was Easter with great weather and I was on vacation so do NOT judge me) the food and the service was great. We had beef bourginion, lamb shank, the crabcakes and a cheese platter. All of it was tasty. Being organic I think I was well aware of a higher quality of ingredients tho,  which was def reflected in the dishes as a whole.  It was really quite in there tho so don't plan on party times.
author: Mike W.

description:
I'll admit, we were biased.  Being the first LEED-certified hotel in CA means something to my group.  Plus, I've been to the building for a tour before and took everyone to the public open space (roof top opens til midnight)!

The food.  Nice.  Flavorful but some dishes were not quite enough to share.

Better yet were the drinks, so it was perfect for a dinner more about the company.

Overall, a hidden gem if you want to dine near Union Square in a calm setting.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I would have given this place negative 1 stars if I could have. 

Pros: ummm

Cons: We were sat and waited 15 minutes. No approach. The server came to both tables on either side of us a couple times and never once acknowledged our presence. I finally got up and went back to the hostess stand to ask for a server (and a manger).  Ok, you're busy. I get it but at least say something or glance our way.  The manager never came.  We asked for a wheat beer and the waitress gave us a dark barley beer.  Then she proceeded to argue with us until my friend googled the beer to prove her wrong.  She still didn't replace it with a wheat beer.  Ok, fine.  We ordered the frites and the ginger chicken to start with.  Both were bad.  The chicken were fancified bone on chicken wings and no flavor (really greasy too).  The waitress came by and told us that our Kobe Burger was almost ready, and then we proceeded to wait for an additional 25 minutes until it came to our table.  It sucked.  Bill came, again we asked for the manager and the waitress informed us that he had already left.  On the way out we overhead the other waitress apologizing to another table for their poor service and subpar meal.  BAD.
author: Meg S.

description:
We ordered room service while staying at the Orchard Garden Hotel that is connected to the restaurant.

As of 2.11.09, the menus in the room are not current. Prices are a little more expensive than what is indicated in the hotel room guide, but the food is still a great value for the price. i just wish they didn't tack on a $5 delivery charge on top of the 20% service charge.

I don't usually order room service, but we were really tired and didn't want to go out. I was expecting the worst, but was delighted when we got some really yummy food. Delivery took 20 minutes, which is what the person on the phone had predicted.

We ordered a chicken sandwich, farmers market soup on a weeknight (that day it was mushroom soup) that came with the best oil and herb dip I have ever tasted in my life (seriously, I wanted to take a straw and slurp it up. oh, is that gross to do that?).

The portion sizes were just right, and the food was excellent. It was a great value, especially considering the food is organic and fresh.

I will rate everything on a 5-point scale:
Mushroom soup = 3/5 ; had croutons in it and the soup was way too salty for my taste; however, it would probably be ok with some people
Chicken sandwich = 4/5 ; served with pickle and organic salad. the sandwich was above average and the salad was very fresh. however, i didn't care too much for the dressing. it was too vinaigretty.
Humboldt Fog Goat cheese = 3/5 ; served with green grapes, filbert nuts, and crostini
Bread (served with oil and herb dip) = 5/5 ; delicious!!! the dip was FANTASTIC, the best i've ever had, and the bread was very soft and fresh.
author: Wendy L.

description:
First things first.....the food is TERRIBLE. I ordered the short ribs and it came out cold. The waitress was apologetic for the chef and offered to bring a new plate. I wasn't feeling very hungry so I asked that it be packed to go. My friend ordered ordered the steak that came out sub-par. Meat was fatty and drowned in lentil guck. Forgot to mention we started with a trout appetizer that was decent to say the least. We also ended the meal with a bread pudding dessert that was also good. High priced menu that isn't worth the price.

My suggestion.......if you're looking for a place to have some drinks and receive good service, this place will give you that. As for a fine dining experience, you get forget about it.
author: jenny y.

description:
Roots has this happy hour special where they offer a free appetizer from 4-7pm w/ the purchase of a mixed cocktail or a glass of wine.   The cocktail is about $12 but it's pretty strong.  We went with a couple of friends and ordered 3-4 different appetizers and the portions were filling enough as a meal.  You must order the fries that are dusted with parmesan and fried in truffle oil... soo soo good.

I give this place 3 stars because the service is slow.  We made reservations at 7pm and there were only 3 other tables that night.  There's only one server and it took us over an hour to get our drinks and appetizers.  

If you have time to kill before heading out, I would definitely recommend coming by for a drink and bite.
author: Cathy L.

description:
Had a top-notch dinner there. Arugula salad was good, bartender's specialty cocktail was delicious and the main courses were excellent! We had the crispy Salmon and and English pea risotto - both of which were cooked to perfection and really delicious. The Chocolate/hazelnut pot de creme was a good choice for dessert. 
Unfortunately (for the restaurant) the place was empty - maybe due to recent change of ownership or the location in a downtown hotel. We did go there with a coupon which made it more affordable, but the meal was amongst the best I have had eating around SF.
author: Helio R.

description:
I won't go back to this restaurant for sure.  I ate there because I bought the Travelzoo voucher.  We walked in the restaurant before this couple.  But we they were serving the couple and taking their orders first until I asked them for some water.  Yeah, finally they noticed us.  We order a salad and two entrees but we waited for 1.5hrs (for a long while we didn't even know where our waitress went) and no one came over to our table to let us know what's going on until I asked them about our orders.  Then, the waitress told us that they only have one chef in the kitchen.  

The food was just average.  When we were ready to order, they were out of four items (4 out of 12!) on the menu.  I seriously thought this restaurant was a joke! We got there 7:30pm and there were less than sixty people eating there and they have no food?!
author: Joanne L.

description:
We came here for happy hour on a gorgeous early spring day.  The roof deck is a nice place to unwind because it's not crazy and scene-y and absolutely perfect for relaxing and soaking up the last few hours of sunshine (gotta love daylight savings!).  

The unfortunate thing is that there is no bar/waitstaff on the roof.  (The bar downstairs is pretty small so I wouldn't really recommend downstairs for happy hour, wait for a sunny day and do the roof.)  You have to order your drinks downstairs at the bar.  They will happily bring stuff up to you on the roof so you can catch the waiter/bartender when he does the delivery, but it's not very frequent.  This makes service pretty slow but its hospitable and friendly.  The bring you fresh baked bread, its warm and delicious.  The fries are yummy too.
author: Linda L.

description: Staying at the hotel, we had breakfast here on our last day. We thought it was very good indeed -- two of us had the Full Breakfast (eggs, potatoes, bacon, english muffin) which was very well prepared and at $12, about half the price of comparable breakfasts at the large business hotels. A third in our party had an omelette which was also exemplary. Good, strong coffee and prompt service rounded out a fine, satisfying start to the day.
author: J. P.

description: Came here today w/ some coworkers and had a lovely lunch.  I got the pesto chicken sandwich w/ an avocado relish and perfectly crisp bacon.  I also really enjoyed their greek salad which had the perfect amount of dressing, cheese & kalamata olives.  I also really liked their housemade spicy pickles - yum!  I received excellent and speedy service, for a sit down lunch in a nice atmosphere, 10 bucks for a drink, salad & entree is a pretty good deal.  I will definitely come back here the next time I need lunch at a reasonably-priced, nice place.
author: Suzanne V.

description:
um... definetly very beige. Service was very bubbly & sweet, but inexperienced. 2 people in our party ordered the clams with chorizo in white wine. This was a very tasty dish minus the sand. I think they FORGOT to scrub the clams. The other 2 of us had salads. Those were fine. Nothing to write home about. 

Flat iron steak: little sinuey/gristly but good flavor. 
Merlot Braised Duck leg:decent flavor served with asparagus & FRIED potato cubes ( not the best choice for a starch, unless you're a 7 year old.)
Halibut: All nice suble flavors except for the pesto vinaigrette thing that just slaps you in the face!

Desserts: almost didn't go there, but banana ice cream... creamy and tasty. 
warm chocolate tart with caramel sauce...................OOHHHHH yum

Finally, as a foodie, I was bummed there was no amuse bouche and NO cheese cart. When you are given the impression that you should get dressed up, you should get an amuse bouche!!! I should have known that the lack of a full house on a Saturday night at 8pm would be a problem...

Overall, the food was fine. The service was nice, and the atmosphere was pleasant. Nothing to write home about.
author: Rosie T.

description:
Through the Dine About Town promotion, a group of my friends and I made reservations at Roots. It's right on the first floor of the Orchard Hotel, and we flowed right from the lobby to our table.

It wasn't crowded at all, which struck me as a little odd. It was clearly dinner time, but there just wasn't a packed house. While this may indicate there's something wrong with this restaurant, the rest of my visit proved it wrong.

We had a wonderful server, who was attentive and open. We ordered 3 bottles of wine and she helped us with our choices. For dinner, I had an Arugala salad, Seared Scallops, and ice cream with fried bananas and chocolate sauce.

The Arugala salad was fantastic and it came with some of the freshest strawberries I've ever had. The whole restaurant only uses organic food, so the freshness of the salad really popped. The scallops were mouth watering, and melted in your mouth. I could have had plenty more.

Dessert was great, the company was great, and I'm sure I'd have a great time here on my next visit.

Thank you Dine About Town! Why don't we just keep this promotion going all year round?
author: Mike K.

description:
It's still pretty sparse during lunch, but the food has been *awesome*.  Perfectly cooked spicy prawns on polenta/grits with smoked bacon.  Perfectly cooked asparagus w/ lemon oil and parmesan.  Perfectly cooked  Niman Ranch burger.  Allegedly perfectly cooked halibut main that my friend had.
