If you don't need to people-watch, this is a killer lunch downtown.  Filling starters and sandos are all around $7-15.  Great deal.  Entrees are more...
author: Melanie C.

description: Bland food , Bland decor, Poor service. Don't waste your money , even if you have a  Travel-zoo voucher.
author: John R.

description: Dis restaurant be classy as hell. No lines, no waits. It'll be some quiet dinna' fo' ya' and yo' honey. Slap mah fro! Dat's it. Man!
author: Yue T.

description: The food was really good yet pricey but the coffee was amazing- seriously the best cup of coffee I've ever had
author: Stari N.

description:
Had a lovely meal at Roots.  Starters and entrees are quite pleasant.
Be forewarned that wine list and dessert menu leave a lot to be
desired.  Be sure to set aside plenty of time, as they enjoy raising
your anticipation level.  But drink a couple of their special martinis
and you'll be kind of glad you did.
author: Patricia A.

description:
Note: this review is for the drinks and appetizer menu only.

I took my office here for a happy hour yesterday afternoon, and it was a great experience.  The bartender, who was working by himself when the 20 of us showed up, was courteous and moved very quickly to make sure everyone had a drink.  The drink menu is inventive and the drinks I tasted were all very tasty and very strong, you definitely get $10 worth of alcohol in their mixed options.

The appetizers we tried were delicious, as were the desserts we had (some sort of chocolate cake and vanilla ice cream and cherry sauce).
The interior is a bit bland and the space is not designed for too many people around the bar, which was my only complaint.  This is a hotel bar, after all, and should have room for all the weary travelers to sit and sip their wonderful raspberry caipirinhas and zentinis.
author: Jessica P.

description:
This place is pretty good. I really enjoyed their appetizers and during happy hour if you buy a drink you get a free appetizer. What get better than that.
Their cheese sampler is amazing. You pay $6 you get toasted bread and some bomb goat cheese. This is a much better deal than going to a cheese store and buying cheese. 
Plus the seafood was great. I was a little down that on their website it says they have a cioppino but they didn't have it when I went in their store since I guess they change their menu.
I wonder why not so many people go there. There is a lot of empty chairs and the sorroundings are all brown which might scare people away??
The one thing that kept met from giving them 5 stars was their music selection. It was awful and depressing 80's music when I went.
author: Nir B.

description:
the clean interior screamed out cali organic and sustainable cuisine.
fun little lettuce leaves were peppered in as centerpieces.

if it wasn't for the drone of loud music and hoots from the bastille celebrations across the way, this was def a quiet setting for deep convo.

the soup of the day  was mushroom soup and it sounded wonderful but i had to try their dungeness mac 'n cheese.
albeit creamy and deelish, it was light on the crab bits.
share or box up half if you don't want to fall into a carb coma.

the goat cheese salad was big enough to share for two.

the pork chop with apple bites was juicy and hearty.

and for you cheese lovers, get the cheese tasting platter with four varietals.  a nutty firm cow, a peppercorn one, a tangy point reyes blue, and my fav...a truffled goat.  slices of apple, candied walnuts, and chunks of strawberry rounded out the plate.

by ten-ish, the place cleared out and we were ready for our next joint.

even with solid service (we did not get the much yelped slow service), the yummy food, and being attached to a hotel...i really hoped this organic spot will survive the recession and truly be sustainable.
author: Anh V.

description:
Came here on a gift certificate and got to enjoy the 1099 special. We ordered the salad lyonnaise, spring vegetable risotto, boeuf bourguignon, and the halibut over cannellini beans ($11 each). Plus we got dessert (ice cream) and the total was $53 with tax. 

So first off, great deal so you should come in April. The portions are smaller than the regularly priced items but still entree sized. We ordered for 2 and it was more than enough food. Food was tasty but a little bit too salty. If they lightened up on the salt I think the essence of the fresh ingredients would really blossom (as they might say on top chef =b). 

The chef was hosting, seating, busing, and serving that night. He was personable and warm, which helped to round this rating to a 4 instead of a 3. He was very excited about his food and restaurants (also is chef at Daffodil) so I hope he does well for himself. 

Service could have been better - staff were friendly and attentive at times and we were ignored at others. Things seemed a little chaotic in the dining room.
author: C K.

description:
having dinner located practically in the lobby of a hotel was a little awkward but otherwise the ambiance was nice. although the reviews haven't been amazing, i had faith in this place. 

the food itself was pretty good for the most part. 
vegan tomato soup with croutons- light and nice however it could have used more umph or more seasoning. 

crab mac n' cheese- delicious and piping hot! although a larger portion would have been nice. 

flat iron steak w/ polenta cakes- quite tasty and texturally nice. the acidity of the leafy greens with dressing matched the creaminess of the polenta very well. but the meat had been noticeably sitting for a bit as it came to the table just slightly above luke warm. 

but the service! AAAAAAHHHHHH the service! it drove me insane!!!! the woman serving us did a fine job as far as being polite when i presented her with a restaurants.com certificate, refilling water, asking if we needed more bread, and giving us proper utensils but DAMN WAS IT SLOW!!! one appetizer and two entrees and we were there for 2 1/2 hours!! even the soup took FOREVER to get to us! soup is premade!! all you have to do is ladle it and bring it out! everything took a lifetime to get to us. we left practically running out because we were tired of being there! i won't be back.
author: Regina C.

description:
My grandfather always used to tell me, "The customer is always right (even when you know they're wrong)".  Apparently the owner of this restaurant instills their waitstaff with not only a slightly different view of things (ie: "argue with your customer to excuse your short-comings"), but also apparently just doesn't train them overall at all.

My wife and I went there with my brother-in-law and his girlfriend.  I'm usually a bit wary of eating at a hotel restaurant but my brother had some sort of coupon that gives you 1/2 off a $100 tab (or something of that sort), so we figured, a good deal overall and Roots was one of the only qualifying restaurants that looked good.

Long story a bit short(er), I've forgotten all the things that bothered me about our experience there were so many issues.  A few off the top of my head:
1) service was PAINFULLY slow - several minutes just to get our menus, several more for them to come over and answer any questions, etc and take our order.  SEVERAL (ie: 20+) more to actually get our food.  And on and on from coming over to ask "how is everything doing here with dinner - do you need anything?", offering and then bringing coffee/dessert, etc.
2) my food was very poorly described - not a huge deal, but it turned out to be a fried dish, which I wouldn't have ordered if they'd described it more accurately (he said it was "kind of like a vegetable meatloaf", which would infer it was baked (false assumption) and which I thought sounded interesting either way.  Turned out to be fancy corn fritters (the only vegetable I could detect) in the shape of a hockey puck.  To their credit, they were reasonably tasty but so NOT what he'd described and had I known they were just fried corn fritters I would've opted for something else.   
3) when I go to a greasy spoon coffee shop, I don't expect "proper serving etiquette".  However, when I go to what appears to be a higher end restaurant (ie: linen table clothes, waitstaff wearing ties, nice decor, etc) I raise my expectations accordingly.  When said (Roots) waitstaff brings us room temperature coffee (clearly been sitting for quite some time) and then proceeds to place our mugs on the table by wrapping their fingers around the rims of the cup (ie: where our mouths are going to go), I'm sorry, but someone did not train you right for...
4) there were at least 3 different significant things on the (fairly limited) menu they ran out of.  And we're not talking, "I'm sorry, the salad these evening no longer has toasted hazelnuts, we've run out"...we're talking "we ran out of the fish dish tonight" (and then a dessert dish and something else notable, can't remember).  I get it - restaurants run out of things on occasion and I don't normally fault them.  But it was a Saturday night, we were there early in the evening and the restaurant was far from full (so it's not like they were selling fish like hot cakes), so someone was clearly not keeping an eye on ordering their stock properly.
5) when we started to get ready to leave, I asked everyone if they thought it appropriate for me to say something to the manager (who was mostly our server that evening).  They said, "Absolutely!", but asked if they could excuse themselves as they embarrass easily.  As I went to speak to the manager and explained that we'd had a very disappointing evening, I attempted to keep it respectable and broad in my complaint and was ultimately met with an attitude of, "soooo,you're feeling service wasn't fast enough for you and you're upset about this one thing?".  And then I'd have to proceed to say, "No, actually, I'm upset about several things - but I didn't want to get into it".  To which he'd respond defensively with, "Well, what else about the evening wasn't to your standards?", to which I had to go into further detail, though still trying to stay respectable.  "Soooo, you're upset that we ran out of a few things and that your coffee wasn't hot enough for you?" ...and on and on, before finally I had to just pull out the stops and list not only all the things that bothered us, but also the fact that I was now having to stand here and JUSTIFY and defend my views as a customer?!  THAT was the perfect and appropriate end to the evening - indicative of the overall experience.  

If you like quiet (ie: no music, awkwardly-so-when-the-restaurant-isn't-full-enough-to-fill-in-the-silence) places and don't have to be anywhere for the better part of the evening.  And if you've snacked before you got here so you're not very hungry while ordering, aren't very committed to what you've ordered as they may not have what you want, and if you enjoy a good argument if you decide to say something about any of the above, then this place is AWESOME!!
author: David M.

description:
I gave it a generous 3 stars because this restaurant has only been opened for 6 months. We got lost trying to find this hotel, and NOBODY we asked knew where this place (or the Orchard Hotel) was. 

We were about an hour late, and turns out it doesn't even matter because there were only 2 or 3 other tables there. Our big party of 6 really made the night fun.. otherwise, I would have gotten out of there ASAP!

Service was REALLY slow, but they were nice. The chef was managing that night, so maybe that's why the food was so slow. The online menu is inaccurate. The "best dish" of the night was the Parmesan fries, followed by the WIld Mushroom Risotto. The short ribs ragout was too sweet, the steak was undercooked (had to send it back), the halibut cheeks tasted really fishy (and you know when you're describing a fish dish as fishy.. something is wrong), and the fried green tomatoes were alright, but it was the squash bloom that was good. Smoked trout was mediocre as well.

Doubt we'll be going back.
author: Natalie Y.

description:
My fiancée and I had reservations here for last night (Friday 2/13).  We walked in, the place was empty save for three people at the bar (who seemed to be friends of the bartender).  We almost chickened out, but I'm glad we didn't.

Appetizers: I ordered the smoked trout salad (very good), and she ordered the mac and cheese with crab (truly excellent).  Main course: we both had the flat iron steak and it was wonderful -- one of the best steaks I've ever had!  I don't remember what we had for dessert (although I do remember it was very good) because I was still in awe from the steak.

And they take pride in their work, too: the waitress apologized for the pot the creme not being available on the dessert menu, because the chef wasn't happy with the way it turned out.

Definitely five stars for the food.  The ambiance could use some work (dim the lights a bit), and don't shy away from coming here -- this isn't your typical hotel restaurant, it's one of the best meals I've had in a while.
author: Tudor B.

description: One of my favorite restaurant. I went for luch. Some people say service is slow, but if you are not in a hurry, it is acceptable. Food is great!
author: Bobby J.

description: Definitely not a hot spot but the food was not bad at all....in fact it was quite delicious!  Try the farmers market soup (for me it was a vegan tomato soup with truffle oil) and the Parmesan truffle french fries (better then Oola's).
author: Wakako U.

description:
I feel torn about Roots. The minute I walked into the place I had misgivings. There is little to separate the restaurant dining room from the (Orchard Garden Hotel) registration desk. The colors were bland...beige on beige. The room was almost totally empty and you could hear a pin drop. Yet...I stayed.

I had a martini at the bar with a friend and was seated quickly (the staff had little else to do). The menus looked good and our waitress was friendly and just a tiny bit quirky. I liked her immediately. Quickly we were served an Amuse Bouche of watermelon consume. Sweet and very fresh.  I'm in an oyster phase right now and opened with a half dozen Marin Miyagi...very fresh with a  nice cucumber mignonette. I went with the dinner special, venison (rare), as my entree and washed it down with a glass of the 2003 Domaine de Cristia grenache/syrah blend.. The game was cooked perfectly and I finished every bit of it. The service was terrific and fun and nonintrusive. The wine list is small but balanced with bottles from all over the world...somebody put care into the selection. Noise level was low (obviously) so my friend and I could talk business.

In another space this place would be a big hit. Its amazing just how the decor of a room can affect your expectations of the meal to come. In its current location Roots is easy to miss. I'm sure much foot traffic just walks right by and that's a shame because Roots has plenty to offer. For a high quality, quiet meal with great service its hard to beat.
author: Gary C.

description:
Essentially, we ate our dinner in a hotel lobby.  One that was nearly empty except for our table of screaming, out-of-control crazies.  Fortunately, our waiter (enticingly named "Talon") was a good sport and did shots with us, posed for photos and revealed his life's dreams.

And the meal itself wasn't bad, except the fritto misto was kind of odd (the deep-fried meyer lemon slices made one of my dining companions wince while another one squeezed it into one of his two cocktails).  We devoured our mac & cheese (with dungeness crab!) and did serious damage to our entrees (my spiced pork loin was especially yummy).

I think that the restaurant lacked character and energy, otherwise it would have been a more exceptional experience.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Came here for dinner b/c I had a $20 off coupon (Groupon - check it out!), and the eco-friendly/organic idea appealed to me (less of a hippie thing than a fresher/natural food tastes better kind of thing).

Drinks:  Coconut mojito was delicious, though my favorite was the Sunset something-or-another-with-gin-lemonade-champagne-and-Chambord.  Pomo-politan was decent too, though I asked for a much less sweet version.  They also offer a list of organic wines, which I would normally have checked out if I hadn't had such a hot cocktail-perfect day of golf, etc.

Food:  To start, we had the arugula salad with goat cheese, fresh figs, and candied walnuts - delicious, but could totally make that at home.  Also tried the crab mac and cheese, which was pretty solid.  The crab was a nice addition to the old favorite.  And the cheese certainly didn't overpower it, though it could probably have complemented the crab better (not sure what cheese, off the top of my head - I'll try to reflect on it and update later).  For entrees, we tried a scallops dish and the pork chop dish.  Scallops were in a delicious sauce, but were quite chewy (very overcooked), which was a little disheartening for the scallop-lover in both of us.  The pork chop was delicious and tender, and the sauce (some sort of red wine and apple juice reduction (maybe?!? forgot to ask!)), though the potato/apple/onion pancake thing accompanying the pork chop left much to be desired (good idea, but bad result - could use more flavor (spices? salt? pepper?  none on the table, so I didn't even try adding anything to it).

Service:  Note that the mac and cheese takes about 15 minutes to bake (and that's just an appetizer - though I would have it as an entree if I had been going solo on it).  So if people have complained of slow service, it's probably just that things are actually fresh AND made to order here.  So yes, that takes time.  Otherwise, I found the service to be attentive, yet not obnoxious or annoying.  Our waiter was helpful in offering specialty cocktail modifications so that they wouldn't be too sweet for me.  We didn't try dessert, mostly because we were full at the time, but also because we had a fresh, homemade apple crisp ready to bake up at home.

Other Notes:  They offer a cheese tasting platter, which, being a cheese-aholic, I would love to try at some point.  I imagine that a cheese tasting platter plus a bottle of organic wine (on one of the many SF nights where it is not 80 degrees out) would be a lovely way to spend the evening.  Also, as others have noted, the place was pretty empty - just the two of us and a party of 5 that had clearly been there for awhile - but it wasn't awkward or weird or overly quiet.

All in all, a good eco-friendly meal.  Probably a tad pricey, but that's also the price you pay for organic, locally grown food (though I expected a little more given the price - thank goodness for my coupon!).  Specialty drinks were pretty amazing though, so I'd recommend checking those out for sure, if nothing else.
author: Kristen H.

description: By far one of the worst dining experiences, especially for the price point, I have ever had.  We waited a long time to be acknowledged by a host (who ended up being the waitress) in a mostly empty restaurant, we had a party of three and we each got a different menu. We waited a very long time for our drinks to come. When we told her our menus were all different she said they had a new bar tender who was learning. When food finally came after a long wait, it was mediocre at best. The halibut was plain and salty, the mac and cheese not creamy, and the duck was drowning in plain beans. Your run of the mill comfort food restaurant does it better - chow for example. The whole green/organic thing is a total gimmick at this place which sucked us in. We felt awkward because of the wait and lack of attention. Also the restaurant ambience is a little strange because it is in a hotel lobby. To top it off the credit card machine needed "restarted" and we got to over hear all the frustration of both waiters.  1 star for the friendly attitude of our server, at least she's nice.
author: Mark S.

description:
I went there for Dine About Town last week.

You feel like you are in a hotel restaurant with simple beige colors and small fresh flowers on every table, but guess what - you are in a hotel restaurant.  I think I expected a different kind of ambiance for some reason.

The food was good (I had the scallops, not that great, but my BF had the spiced pork which was out of this world).  Their full bar and wine list was nice.

I probably wouldn't go back here unless I got a deal (like Dine about Town).  I think this restaurant is suitable for a business lunch or dinner, not a night out with friends or even a romantic dinner.
author: Carol S.

description:
Roots....
Hard to describe this restaraunt.  The the food itself was pretty good and the service was good but a bit amateur in the sense that when I asked the waitress what the food is like she had the same description for everything in that everything is sustainable, organic and farm raised.

The restaraunt ambience was a bit strange.  It is bascailly locatged directly in the lobby of the hotel.  Very small.  I may have been there during a strange time as some company was having a small happy hour there.  We went in at 7 PM and we were the only ones there.

When it came to the food though.  It was very delicious.  I had the roasted chicken with the risotto.  The chicken was very juicy and the risotto done with plenty of flavor.  It made it so the chicken wasn't too bland.

Overall.  if you were to want to try this place out go for it.  Not the best of all restaurant environments but the food may make up for it for you.
author: Patrick T.

description: Pretty decent spot here but nothing too special either. The crab mac and cheese was not all that good but interesting. The hangar steak was really good, perfectly cooked and good meat. Service was also great, we had a very friendly, professional and experienced waitress. Prices were a little steap but given that it's in a hotel and right downtown it's not that suprising. On another day I would probably have given 4 stars. Worth a shot with a coupon.
author: M L.

description:
my best friend took my wife and I here for my birthday, and at first I thought this was a soul food place because of it's moniker, but i was told this was one of those only-in-san francisco- fresh sustainable farming california cuisine places.

god forbid I order some foster farms chicken here or a Happy meal..they would probably stab my ass with their hemp-made spears. 

This place is inside this nice, boutique hotel and we were seated right away. I know that this kind of food was small .. but i really had no idea HOW small until I ordered the Grilled Romaine Salad with bacon and bleu cheese when the waiter served my plate, and there was literally ONE bloody romaine leaf with a few crumbles of cheese and bacon. I looked at the waiter and thanked him for the cheese,..but I asked where the salad was. behold my surprise when he pointed at the leaf and said that was the salad. Sure, it was a great tasting grilled romaine leaf..but i refuse to call it a salad. It was a grilled leaf.

I ordered the 15 dollar organic beef naturally raised and all that. It was good, and tasty, but for fifteen bucks, you could have topped off the burger with an egg, avocado, something! I just got the beef patty, bun, onions, and tomato. 

the pear sorbet i had for dessert was actually dynamite, so that was def. the highlight of the evening. 

will i go back? probably not. Will i only eat sustainable food from now on? Not likely, as my poor wallet could not sustain that lifestyle. but was i full? I actually was! not thanks to the grilled leaf though...
author: Jerry C.

description: Hm. The quinoa salad was good, not great. The risotto was inexcusably bland until  I doused it with shredded parmesan, salt and pepper, at which point it was just okay. The panna cotta was exceptionally good. Overall, wouldn't give the restaurant a second chance.
author: Kay R.

description:
My family went to Roots for Thanksgiving. When we arrived the restaurant was fairly empty, despite this, the service was HORRIBLE. The waitress had a terrible attitude and took a long time for any request we had (from bread, to cheese, to the picking up the bill). The food was good, but not worth the the price. It was a fixed prix menu of $45 for a soup/salad, 4 ravoili and a deseret. It did not even include tea or coffee. 

I asked to speak to a manager and he made no effort to make our experience any better. 

Sadly, I would not recommend this place. Save your money and go somewhere better.
author: ItsTheJourney Q.

description: Even though I normally don't eat in Hotel restaurants I decided to give this one a shot. I was a little taken back that as soon as you walk in the front door, you're in the restaurant! It's a little off. But anyway... Great happy hour. My husband had an amazing aspargus soup with truffle oil!! Then he had the hanger steak which was also delicious and I had the crab mac & cheese. I agree with another yelper that it really only had 2 pieces of crab in it but I still thought it was good. I also had a strawberry mojitio which was great. Overall it was ok. Good things and so so things. The waitress was very nice and helpful as well. I have to think about if I'll return.
author: lisa v.

description: Is it the hour to get HAPPY?! After an afternoon shopping in Union Square or touring Chinatown, head over to the Orchard Hotel's Roots Restaurant for their Happy hour special. From 4-7p.m. you'll receive a free appetizer with the purchase of any delicious drink. Their cocktail menu is creative -branch out and try a Pomopolitian (Cosmo with pomegranate vodka) or a flavored mojito. For around $9-12 bucks you'll receive a strong, refreshing drink and some fine food. Don't miss out on this downtown deal - the Roots Happy hour special is a steal!
author: Caroline J.

description:
surprisingly good! you could have shot a cannonball through the dining room without scratching a soul here but don't let the lack of hipness turn you away from this downtown gem. they take much pride in the freshness of their ingredients and it shows in the delicious dishes you'll savor, like farmer's market soup, truffle oil infused fries (better than the ones at oola, which is my benchmark in SF), and crackin' fresh pork chops. the chops were a bit well done for my taste but they were so tasty that i really didn't mind that much at all. one dish that failed to live up to the hype was the dungeness crab mac and cheese. uninspiring and uncheesy. more like a crab casserole if you ask me. 
anyway, if you don't mind the lack of cachet, pop on into the lobby of the orchard hotel and get ready to be pleasantly surprised.
author: Brett W.

description:
We had dinner here about a week ago and I'm sorry to say that we were disappointed.  We had very high hopes for this restaurant given that it was Cali/Med using orgainic ingredients.   

Here's how the night went:

Appetizers:  We started out with the Panznella salad with Bloomsdale spinach, chanterelle mushrooms and truffle tremor cheese ($11).   The pieces of bread were soaked too much with the vinegar sauce that made us cough upon placing it in our mouth because of the strength of the vinegar.   It's like sniffing a bowl of hot vinegar water.   We stayed away from the wine as we tried to finish this appetizer but couldn't.  Ugh!

Main Course:  The waitress recommended the cassoulet ($23) so I decided to try it.  The description said that it had house-made duck sausage so I was very excited.  When the dish arrived I was first amused by the fact that it came in a Asian clay pot but wait.......the duck sausage was more like duck sausage patties (not sausage in casing).  I felt misled...ugh!   The duck confit was good but where was the pork?  In addition, there were only a few beans and filled halfway with the broth as if I was eating a bowl of soup.   To top it off the chef decided to add diced yams which was too sweet for this dish.   That really ruined the comforting and savory flavors that I was hoping for.   

My dining partner had the red wine braised short ribs over blanched spinach and a huge mound of mashed yams ($23)  The ribs were tender and delcious  however it didn't go well with the sweetness of the yams and the citrus dressing over the spinach.  There were just too many flavors in this dish.   If this was more of a simple dish with regular potatoes and a slightly seasoned blanched veggie it would have been so tasty and comforting.  

Why is it that restaurants often think that a meal should be filled with so many contrasting flavors and large portions?   I would rather have a great meal with simple flavors that allow me to truly enjoy the real flavors of the produce/meat that I'm eating especially if it's organic/sustainable.  I really prefer quality over quantity.

Dessert:  The dessert was really unimpressive.  I ordered the bread pudding that was about 3/4" thick and was cut like a terrine.  The texture of the pudding was more like mousse and didn't  have any taste.   I don't know about you but when I see bread pudding on the menu I think of a nice hearty slice that has chunks of bread.  My dining companion had a chocolate tartlet and that was fair but the chocolate that the pastry chef used did not have the WOW factor.   Both of the desserts were priced around $7.50.   

Wine:  We brought our own wine and after looking at the wine list we were very happy that we did.  Corkage:  $20.

The interior of this restaurant is very sterile too because it's all beige and white.  The day that we had dinner there were only three people in the restaurant. 

The total bill for the evening was a little over $100 which to me was not worth it for the quality of the food.    I really hope for the best for this restaurant.   Unfortunately I don't think I will be going back.
author: Oscar F.

description:
our relationship with roots started so well . . .

my roommate and i went to roots, as many yelpers here, with a restaurant.com certificate.  as others have noted, it was pretty empty on a thursday night.  the hostess/bartender was sweet (although i do not quite understand why she offered us the option of 'cuddling' in the booth) and the cocktails were incredible.  i had a gin-based drink with prosecco and chambord, and my roommate had a much sweeter cocktail with coconut rum and pineapple juice - both from their specialty cocktail menu.  my roommate declared it the best cocktail she has ever had.  and, like another reviewer, i could have slurped up the bread dipping sauce with a straw.  four thumbs up for the bread.

and then came the food . . . eventually . . .

yelper-predicted slow service.  check.  we didn't mind too much.  we split the dungeness crab mac & cheese.  while it was tasty, it fell short of our benchmark for seafood mac & cheese dishes (lobster mac & cheese at first crush).  what really underwhelmed us was the entree - we shared the hanger steak (i broke from my mostly vegetarian ways since roots sources their meat sustainably) with garlic mashed potatoes and asparagus.  meh.  salty.  neither of us liked the potatoes; they were heavy and had a strange taste about them.  hm.

i will come back for cocktails and perhaps that much-yelped-about happy hour special.  and will pass on the food.  disappointed.
author: Pam M.

description:
another yelper with a restaurant.com certificate.. but it was so worth it! 

i agree with everyone out there.. so few people on a wednesday night! and i could see how service would get slow, but for us it was fantastic. 

there were a total of 2 servers plus the bartender in the restaurant, and it was slow but there was a big party in the back, and we never felt neglected. one server even accidentally poured my friend's water sans ice with ice.. and even when she said it was okay, the waiter made a point to replace it with the correct request. 

after seeing some of these reviews, i regret not trying any cocktails, but i have to say i enjoyed their selection of organic and sustainable wine. i had a fantastic cabernet, and my friend had a really yummy rose. there was a mis-pour at the bar, so our server gave us a glass of chardonnay on the house. 

as recommended.. we ordered the crab macaroni and cheese and the mushroom risotto. since we were sharing, we had the server bring these out together. the mac-and-cheese was SO delicious!!! i have to say, i would return just for that. the risotto was good, but not as good as the macaroni. the bread came out a little late, but it was warm, and, like everyone else, i could have drank the dipping sauce. amazing!

the food was very rich, so we were too full for dessert.. but the dessert drinks looked really good!

the only cons i had were the time it took to get acknowledged at the host stand, and the fact that this 'green business' has paper menus. i hope they recycle. in the end, i decided i would definitely return, and definitely recommend it to a friend.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
I recently dined at Roots and was, for the most part, rather impressed. Located inside of the Orchard Garden Hotel, a location recently renovated to be entirely "green" as dictated by the Leeds scale, Roots Restaurant extends the theme of being earth-friendly by not only offering organic and locally grown ingredients whenever possible, but being a "green" business as well. 
I asked the waiter to order for me and was pleased with his advice. The amuse bouche was a duck confit on endive followed by an appetizer of ahi tartare with jalapeno, blood orange and avocado coulis. I feel that they both could have used a little more spice and the tartare, although good, lacked a bit of acid to have made it really great. Next was a Caesar salad with grilled romaine. The dressing was almost perfect and grilling the romaine was a nice touch. For the entree, I was given a bloody rare, grass-fed cow with a potato pancake and Swiss chard. As an accompaniment, I was also ordered seared scallops topped with chorizo served with fingerling potatoes and leeks. The steak and scallops were great but it was the potato pancake and the leaks which really did it for me; the pancake flaky and crisp, the leaks soft and vegetal. Dessert was half an order of chocolate cake a la and half an order of rhubarb crisp. Both quite good.
The interior of the restaurant, which, upon entering, seems almost too close to the hotel's front desk, is actually very private. The decor is done in soothing, cool colours which brought to mind the freshness which the chef seeks in choosing local, organic ingredients. Bathrooms and halls were spotless.
Above all, I was extremely pleased with the service. Both the waiter and the manager, Fritz, seemed genuinely happy to give me a tour of Roots Restaurant's wonderful menu.
author: Daniel W.

description:
This place was unbelievably bad.  I ordered one drink and vowed to never set foot back here:

I stopped in for a drink because out-of-towners were visiting and staying at the Orchard Garden Hotel (Roots is in the lobby).  So I asked the bartender for a very easy cocktail: grey goose martini, up, no vermouth, twist.

Bartender COMPLETELY blew it; and I should know, I've spent a ton of time behind the bar.  

Anyway, he starts by pouring the wrong vodka - I stop him and say, "oh, sorry I thought I said grey goose" - he politely says, "I didn't hear that but this is our house vodka; it's organic and made from blah blah blah" (I had tuned him out at this point).  

Not wanting to appear like a complete jerk in front of guests I was meeting for the first time, I said, "ok, I'll try it."  Then, he pours the vodka into the glass and immediately plops an olive into the martini glass.  Hey barkeep!  Last time I checked, "a twist" is not code for a F*ing olive!  Anyway, I remind him that I said twist.  So then instead of just cutting his losses and starting over with grey goose, he pours the "house" vodka BACK into a shaker with new ice and RE-SHAKES IT (uhh, yup, you guessed it, further watering down the martini).  At this point, I'm smiling (because I don't want to ream the guy in front of guests) so then he puts the finishing touches on the drink: the twist.  A twist, as everyone reading this site knows, is simply a large piece of a lemon peel.  My friend at the bar decided instead to tear up a huge piece of lime and pull all of the pulp off and drop that into my drink.

So not only did my martini [a] taste crappy (not the grey goose I ordered), [b] watered down (shaken over ice 2x), and [c] gimlet-y (the whole lime debacle) but homeboy then looks me in the eye and says "That will be $11, sir."

How can you be THAT bad??  Are you kidding me?  Never again, Roots!
author: Cody K.

description: A friend and I were here on Sunday and I am truly surprised they didn't have more people dining there. Okay, there was our table and then a couple seated behind us. It was dead. I don't know why because the food and drink is so very good. I just wanted to update because this is a place that needs to be given a chance. The food is good and dinner was about $88 including drinks and there was a ton of food. Not the cheapest restaurant out there but certainly very good. Service was very attentive. Very much recommended.
author: Anita B.

description:
I found out about Roots on restaurant.com,  I yelped it and found decent reviews on Roots. So I got the certificate and went there last night with 2 gfs. It was a sweet deal, not only we got $50 off our $100 bill, I also received 1,000 points on opentable! 

I liked the clean and simple interior design of the restaurant, and it was definitely a good place for us girls to have girlie talks. I noticed the menus were different from their online menus, was a little disappointed they didn't have the dayboat scallops which other Yelpers recommended. We started off with the arugula salad, it was so good! The strawberries, the candied pecans and the goat cheese went so well with the greens. It took them a little while to prepare our entrees, so we got a complimentary order of the organic french fries with truffle oil. I am not a big fan of french fries, but those were really yummy!

One of my girls and I had the seabass, it was flavorful, I really liked the greens that came with it. My other gf got the fettuccini and shrimp scampi. BTW, they make their pasta from scratch daily. Both of my gfs actually ordered the fettuccini entree, but they only had enough pasta to make one order, as the pasta they made that day wasn't satisfactory enough, so the chefs refused to serve it to customers. 

We were a little disappointed with the dessert variety. They were serving gelato with rum, fresh baked cookies and croissant blueberry pudding. We had the cookies (we got a macaroon, a peanut butter cookie, a choc chip cookie, a snickerdoodle, an oatmeal raisin cookie) and the croissant pudding, the cookies were really fresh and scrumptious  As for the croissant pudding, it was a little dry and bland. 

Overall, the dining experience at the Roots was very pleasant, we enjoyed our meal a lot and were very stuffed after that!
author: Lynn C.

description: Came here for a business lunch yesterday and the place was EMPTY. Seriously. There was one other table seated at 12:15 on a Thursday. The food was OK, although the vegetarian options were not great (although the menu was pretty brief generally). I had the turtle bean (similar to black bean) soup, which was rather bland, and the fettucine with roasted red pepper sauce (from the Dine About Town menu) which was just rather boring. My dining companions who got the steak sandwich seemed very pleased, however. The desserts (bread pudding and brownie with sauce/ice cream) were delicious if not particularly inventive. All in all, it seemed like a better place for tourists staying at the hotel of which the restaurant is a part than locals looking for tasty downtown eats.
author: Gaelen X.

description: We had the trout salad which was simple yet very good.  The truffle fries were pretty plain, it needed a dip.  The meal came to a crashing halt when we had the scallops over a bed of braised napa cabbage and shitake mushrooms.  It was way too salty.  They forgot to balance soy sauce with sugar.
author: C t.

description: Get past the Beige on Beige on Beige interior (even more beige at lunch when the white table cloths are removed) and this place has a really great menu.  The arugula and strawberry salad was good, and the ribs.. FANTASTIC!  I have yet to eat a whole meal here, because happy hour is so welcoming (free app with drink! 4:30-7pm) and the location is right downtown and perfect for a quick stop after work.
author: Rachel W.

description: The reason I came to try Roots was because I had a gift certificate that was purchased thru Restaurant.com last year in November and it was close by to the area that I was going to be in. The Hostess/waitress/bartender/busgirl showed us to our table and gave us our menu then I showed her the gift certificate that I had she informed us that they no longer accept it. I thought it was very kind of her to give us the option to either stay for dinner or we could leave. She explained to us that she  would understand if we wanted to leave and go somewhere else since we couldn't use the gift certificate. We decided to stay and found the food to be really delicious. I had Crispy Salmon and my husband had the Kobe Burger which he really enjoyed. I tried the grilled Salmon and it was laid on top of a bed of salad. I'm not a big fan of salad but the salad was dressed with some type of Ginger dressing and it was YummY! The Ginger dressing was not overpowering where it would take away the flavoring of the veggies. The Salmon was cooked to perfection. It was not dry and over-cooked. There was yellow beets accompanying the salmon and I thought it was just ok. But everything else was very nicely done and made just right.
author: Jamie W.

description: My inner tree hugger really, really wants to like this place a lot, but I am afraid I probably won't be back for another completely non-memorable meal. I never knew locally sourced, organic food could be so boring.
author: Angie R.

description: I recently had dinner at Roots Restaurant which is inside the Orchard Garden Hotel. The place is very small  but the food is very, very good and huge on taste. Roots only uses the  highest in quality ingredients on each and every item on their menu. By the way portions are very generous. Check out the happy hour menu
author: Ernesto C.

description: Very disappointing! I was so looking forward to the crab mac and cheese because I love mac and cheese and it was flavorless! How this is possible I don't know? The happy hour is very good here though, if you order a drink you get a free appetizer and the appetizers were pretty good. We ordered the truffeled fries, caprese and an arugula salad, all were pretty good but nothing that knocked my socks off. I would maybe try this place for a glass of wine and a free appetizer but wouldn't pay for dinner again here.
author: Heather F.

description: On our recent trip to Roots, January 2010, we were once again delighted with the food and the service.  The food here is delicious.  Have been here several times and have never had a bad meal.   Our server, Cory was very pleasant and very attentive, but not intrusive.  We enjoyed talking with him and learning a little about San Francisco.  Can't say enough about the food.  Mac and cheese is a great appetizer for two and the entrees were awesome.  Try and save room for dessert because they are unbelievable.
author: Marlee O.

description:
I was glad to hear that "Roots" was so unprepossessing, because the place is a sleeper. The food was fantastic ... well prepared and beautiful presentation. The beef was amazingly good, and a really big portion. The salads were all beautiful and delicious, with farmers' market ingredients like baby lettuce, lovely fresh corn on the cob, etc. The fish of the day was wonderful, very moist and perfectly grilled. For dessert, our party shared a plate of fresh, still warm cookies for dessert, right out of the oven. And great coffee, too. I was really impressed. It's very quiet, easy to converse. Quite close to all the theaters. In fact, they rushed our service so we could make our curtain on time.
We were able to bring our 19 month old rascally granddaughter, and they treated her like a princess ... special seat, glass, bread and soup served early just for her. 
An under-the-radar gem. Why isn't this place in Zagat yet? We will definitely be back.
author: Eileen A.

description: So sad, this used to be a very good restaurant.  We went there last year for Valentine's Day and it was fabulous so I bought the travelzoo voucher when it came across.  Then on travelzoo they said it was extended because the restaurant was closing down and would reopen with a new menu and a new name and that the voucher would be good for a combination of food and beverage up to the $109.  The reason for the change it seems is because the food prices are significantly lower and the menu doesn't offer the same appeal as before.   If I was rating the waitress I would give 5 stars, she was great.  The other waiter and the chef (who tried to pass off as the manager) were completely lame.  In addition, the waitress said she was leaving the manager a message to call or email me and of course he/she never did  We had the french fries which were really good.  The pea risotto was ok- actually it was better the next day heated up for left overs.  My husband really liked the Caesar Salad and Salmon. The dessert was butterscotch chocolate and it was pretty good.  All in all I won't go back because the food was not that great and in a city of infinite options, why go somewhere that has mediocre food and has bad management.
author: Jill b.

description: Nothing special for this place. Quite pricy.
author: Leya P.

description: Roots inside The Orchard Garden Hotel is worth a try.  The service was lovely and didn't rush the meal.  Get one of their signature drinks to start.  Also even if you don't like mushrooms, the mushroom bisque is amazing.  Each dish had lovely presentation and normal human portions.
author: Mackenzie O.

description: The food is really good, I loved the bread and herb oil. I highly recommend the mac 'n cheese with crab. It is very filling and you might not need another entree. I had a salad, the steak sandwich and the apple tarte. All were very tasty, although I liked the salad the best. I also tasted the scallops my friend order - fantastic! Can't wait to eat here againa nd try some other dishes. The only negative note - the service was a bit slow, although I am beginning to think this is a SF issues, since the service always seems slow to me in the city. Our server was nice and very helpful, we just didn't see her for awhile. She was the only server we did see, so maybe someone called in sick - there is a cold going around. All in all, I liked this place and look forward to going here a again.
author: Candida R.

description: I've been here several times now...Great place at the foot of Chinatown, in a hotel. It's a great, quiet option for lunch on a busy weekend, during the day. You know the hustle and bustle of Chinatown and the cafes around it...but it's like a little get-away here with good food and coffee. The regular coffee is quite good.  I didn't realize about the happy hour! dang.  their fries are good. so is the hamburger....desserts were good too.
author: Bing B.

description: I almost didn't come here based on earlier Yelp reviews, but am glad I did.  Food is fresh and delicious and unique enough to warrant a visit.  I had the trout and apple and dungeness crab mac and cheese - both are well done, have the "organic fresh taste," and hit the spot.  The room was empty on a saturday night as the other reviews suggested, but that is moreso because it's in a hidden away spot and not for lack of quality.  The service was also decent.  They accidentally gave my friend just  "cheese" instead of "mac and cheese," but we got comped desert for that error.
author: Mark P.

description:
as jessica B. has said, DON'T COME HERE! well, only because i don't want this place to become overcrowded once people realize how AMAZING there food is! mind you i only went for a quick lunch and ordered 2 things but the menu looked very appetizing and i promised myself i would come here for dinner tonight!! 

i had the walnut and strawberry salad with the garlic and truffle oil fries. the fries were FINGER LICKING good!!!!! fried to perfection with just the right amount of garlic on them..not too overpowering. and the salad was fresh and soo tasty with the creamy goat cheese and sugary walnuts. :)) yumyumyum

i encourage you to try this place out even though it looks hidden away and it is quite small, but the food is TOP NOTCH and the ingredients are 100% fresh!!

one qualm....... there was a slight mix up with our food but...hopefully this 4 star will switch to a 5 star once i go in again for another meal
author: Diana C.

description: introduced through Travel Zoo coupon and all four of us completely satisfied and will definitely will return at full price/ It was two wks ago and cannot remember the details of each plate at this point but it was a superb meal with a very good selection of wines in a wide range of prices.  We shared  two deserts which could not have been better.
author: bill s.

description: The food here is tasty.  The location is fine.  It's oddly located seemingly in the lobby of a hotel.  But the decor is nice and the ambience is quiet because it doesn't seem like they get a lot of customers.  But for the waitservice, I'd give this place 3.5 stars.  But our waitress?!  Oh my.  Brusque, impatient, dismissive, unknowledgeable.  She took my wine glass away in a huff when I said I wanted to wait until I ordered dinner to select my wine.  I had to ask for the wine list back and a wine glass!  She was I think the worst person I have had wait on me in a restaurant in years - I was tempted to give her a penny tip.  Lucky for her, my husband paid the bill.
author: Kaui D.

description:
I went here for a business dinner expecting something truly awesome:  a high end, locally sourced restaurant.  Unfortunately, it turned out to be a bit of disappointment.

While the food was decent (I had the tofu misto, and the scallops with bacon) and the wine list was solid, it was ultimately an uninspired meal.  The menu seemed to hold very little originality, and while the service wasn't bad, it certainly wasn't very good either.  The dessert was probably the most underwhelming part of the meal, with the waitress "surprising me" by bringing me the same thing as another member of our party.  Surprise!

Ultimately, I won't be going back to Roots: it was worth a try, but the experience was thoroughly mediocre.
author: Patrick P.

description:
Bummer, bummer, bummer. I really wanted to like Root's because I like their concept and want to support restaurants that use sustainable & organic products. The ambiance was fine, although the restaurant was pretty empty for a Friday night. 

As for service, it was really friendly, but really slow. It took about 30 minutes to get our cocktails, and at that point, there were only 3 other tables in the restaurant. Our food was also really slow. All in all it took about 3.5 hours for us to finish our meal. Granted, we were chatting and taking our time, but the service was sooo slow. And it didn't make sense. The place was almost empty. Clearly their systems are inefficient and I got the feeling there wasn't much oversight in the kitchen or the front of the house.

The food was "OK," which isn't good enough in San Francisco, where we have so much amazing food. I had the flat-iron steak which was undercooked and only OK. A friend of mine had a vegetarian dish that she ended up sending back (she mentioned it was the first time she's ever sent something back in a restaurant). She reported the pasta was overcooked and tasteless. The server was gracious and appropriate in her response, comping my friend's entree and offering her a free dessert.

Overall, we were really disappointed with our experience, primarily with the food (although the slowness of the service was somewhat annoying and perplexing). If they were to get more oversight to improve the efficiency of the service and quality/consistency of the food, they might fare better.
author: Celeste M.

description: Despite the rather bland interior, the food was surprisingly good!  The organic preparations were wonderful and the 'green' theme made you feel extra special.  The portions are very generous and I would definately recommend this joint!
author: sHoo o.

description: We went for Thanksgiving dinner after reviewing the menue and reviews on Open Table and Yelp. It was not good.  The attmosphere is fair, but the service and food were mediocre at best. We did the wine pairing with  dinner, but had to remind the server at each course to bring the glass of wine. The food was cold and pretty much tasteless. The dessert, creme brule was scorched, and the bread pudding was just plain bad.  The price was high,  $ 65, for caffetera quality food.
author: Kathi J.

description: If it was only based on the food and wine I would give this a 5+, however the waitress was horrible!!!  She was slow (there were no other tables she was waiting on).  She then "forgot" to subtract the restaurant.com coupon.  I get home and then I notice on my credit card she charges the wrong price and the correct price!
author: likes t.

description:
So I was stressing about finding a nice, quiet place in the FiDi where I could have a work-related lunch with 1 vegan, 2 vegetarians, 2 pescetarians, 1 veggie inclined converted carnivore and one normal person.  The Roots menu happily suited us all, especially since the delish soup of the day (tomato with a swirl of pesto) was vegan.   So, food, probably four stars.

However, I have to echo comments that imply that Roots is still a little rough around the edges. Service was very earnest and polite, but spacey - forgot to bring us bread, forgot a side and was slow with water - even though I think there were only three tables full in the place.  The owner-host was very friendly.  This was great the time I went there for a happy hour and he chatted us up at the bar and gave us an appetizer special.  For lunch with the chair of our board, though, he was just a wee bit intrusive.  Also, while I was very pleased with our quiet secluded banquette, apparently my co-workers on the other side of the table were distracted by ambient noises and odd music choice.  (The Bee Gees?  Celine Dion?  Come on, not quite matching the classy decor).  Also, I filled up just fine on my moderately priced and generous soup-and-salad choices, but ended up letting my friend graze because she still looked hungry after her tiny mound of $18 risotto.

I would go here again for a professional lunch if I wasn't in a rush (anything over $10 - ok, anything over brownbag from home - is too expensive for me when I'm not on the corporate credit card).  Again, the food was tasty and seemed healthy and fresh, and it's very close to my office.  Just hope that they work out the service and ambiance kinks.
author: Gloria B.

description: Love the idea of this place therefore thought I would give it a try while I was in town.  The food was perfectly prepared.  However, the place was empty during our dinner at 8:30PM on a Thursday.  Wish this restaurant well and hopefully more people give it a try.
author: Daniel H.

description:
Just tried out their new spring menu last Saturday. It was really, REALLY good!!! 
First off, the waitress (Lynn?) told me that they're rolling out their menu and she asked if she could pick the items for me. Loved the idea.
Started with the crab cakes. No fillers, all Dungeness crab. Great spice. Nice little creme fraiche dipping sauce to take off the heat. Glass of white. Then on to the lamb shank. Yowza! What a portion...and what a deal!!! Meat fell off the bone, dauphine potatoes were just right. Served with collared greens. Cool idea. Lynn had recommended a glass of red wine - perfect. Very little room left for dessert, so I chose a white chocolate mousse. It came with a chocolate cake - so after the 3 courses and 2 glasses of wine I was feelin' good!
Kitchen crew came out and asked for feedback. Such nice guys.
Will be back for sure to try the other spring menu items. This place deserves more attention and support!!!
author: Betsy C.

description: We had a horrible dining experience at Roots.  This place is a coffee shop masquerading as haute cuisine.  We had to return two dishes (one was woefully undercooked and the other was full of dead lettuce), and the food just wasn't that good.  Wildly overpriced for what you get and poor service.  About the only good thing I will say about Roots is that it was clean. I would pass on this one.
author: Bill J.

description: Tried this place for Valentine's Day.  The service was great - very friend waiter with lots of good suggestions.  He didn't know much about the house wine (Cabernet from Chile) but that was OK.  Started with arugula and goat cheese (Humboldt Fog) salad w/ beets.  Not enough beets, too much cheese.  Then had the seared scallops with leeks and potatos.  The potatos were boring.  The scallops were cooked perfectly.  My complaint though with that dish was that there were only 4 scallops. For $22 I expected 6.  Dessert was chocolate fondue -- very tasty, very lame presentation.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
first, i want to say that i stay in a LOT of hotels.  a lot.  and it is a rare thing for a hotel restaurant to offer such lovely, thoughtful food.  if i were traveling alone i could easily make a dinner out of the happy hour special which is:  buy a full price drink and get a free appetizer.  
my husband and i split an arugula salad which came with goat cheese, ripe peach, and candied pecans.  the kitchen put the salad on separate plates for us at no charge - it was definately more civilized than passing back and forth (or reaching over each other).  i ordered the fish of the day (cod) served with white beans and spinach which was satisfying, but definately over salted.  so far, so good.  
the real problem of the evening was that the waitress, who offered timely and attentive service, kept pushing us to order the MOST expensive item on the menu.  it was SO transparent that no matter what we asked about the menu, she kept going back to the most expensive item on the menu.  finally, we narrowed my husbands meal choice down to the 3 pasta dishes. 
i should explain here that my husband has the appetite of a teenage boy.  when i make dinner at home he will have 3 heaping plates of food (he's skinny, BTW, so i can't begrudge him his appetites).  so we plainly asked the waitress which pasta dish came with the MOST food?  i clearly stated that we were looking for "quantity and not quality."  now she was hell bent on selling us the most expensive pasta dish,  she forced the crab tortelloni on us.  when the plate arrived there were 4 (maybe 5) pieces of tortellini (smaller than tortelloni).  meanwhile, the super cheap pasta of the day (a volcano shaped pile of homemade pasta with a humble bolognese sauce) marched past our table; my husband drooled over it's shameless volume.
the "bread" that roots served were actually sweet corn cakes.  they were very light, moist, and crumbly, served with a basil infused oil.  they were more like dessert than "bread."  we really needed something with more "body" to finish the bit of sauce left from the pasta (there was so little of it that my husband was determided to finish every drop).  my dish was also very liquidy at the bottom, but neither of us had a spoon.  it was weird timing that when we needed it, there was no one to ask for a spoon.  my husband caught the bartenders eye and she was happy to bring us more corn cakes to facilitate the consumption of the precious sauce.
we are not naive, we know that waitstaff upsell wines and entrees to get the total bill up in order to boost their tip.  but in this case it was just so sad and transparent.  
while waiting for my husband to arrive our waitress brought over the pasta of the day (the fish of the day too).  the plates were on their way to 2 other diners in the room, and at the time i considered it very thoughtful of the server to give me a sneek peek at the actual goods.  i knew that the pasta dish would come close to satisfying my husbands huge appetite and i found it hard to believe when she told us that the crab pasta was actually MORE FOOD.  we were just so clear about what we wanted.
my husband left hungry and stewing in his own juices of resentment.  he felt tricked and lied to.  no amount of food can fill that hole.
author: passion f.

description: Like some of the other reviewers, I was very surprised by the excellent food and service.  The organic chicken confit was excellent, perfectly cooked juicy meat with a nice crisp skin.  The risotto with mushrooms was very well done as well.  The flat iron steak was above average.  Portions are  HUGE.  The reason for -2 stars, is the ambiance and decor.  Like the other reviewers, I gotta echo the complaints on the space.  The feel of the restaurant is a bit awkward.  I think the addition of doors and/or different lighting could improve the feel of the restaurant.  The place feels a bit too sterile and needs separation from the hotel's lobby.
author: Kazuo L.

description:
Simply bad food, the chef here has no idea of how strong vinegar can be in a panzanella salad, it made me cough!! the short ribs I had, were served with sweet potatoes, yes, sweet potatoes with a sweet sauce over the ribs...

I might go back, but not in a long, long time..
author: Marianne F.

description: Yummy in our tummy!  We went to eat at Roots, before seeing Wicked at the Orpheum.  It was a perfect meal for a perfect evening.  We arrived at the restaurant at 5:15pm and they were having Happy Hour.  The appetizers were wonderful and we had truffle-oil/garlic fries and an arugula salad with champagne vinaigrette.  I am not a fan of salad dressing, but this was a dressing I could drink.  It was light and so flavorful- the best dressing I have ever had.  My main dish was  a mushroom risotto- oh so tasty.  My husband was jealous, but his fettuccine was also very, very tasty.  The bread brought to our table was fresh from the oven and the olive tapenade was amazing.  The server was so friendly and so knowledgeable.  Everything was made and brought to the table with such care.  We were so happy!  It was nice and quiet, being a Tuesday, and while it is in the side lobby of a hotel, it felt very, very private.  It was wonderful food and we will be sure to come back.
author: Steal R.

description: Great new restaurant downtown.  Wonderful seasonal flavors at reasonable prices even with an almost completely organic menu! The duck liver mousse is a must to begin with! For an entree we absolutely loved the braised duck leg with a sweet potatoe gratin.  Perfect for a cold San Francisco night!
author: liz r.

description: Dynamite location matched by equally dynamite food.  Thank God the chef has decided against butter and bread, and has opted for paper thin slices of toasted baguette with fresh olive tapenade to begin your meal.  I enjoyed the lamb ribs in a pomegranate glaze so much I might swear off pork ribs for the rest of my life; however, nothing can top the duck liver mouse.  It absolutely melts in your mouth!
author: Leyla A.

description: "Song who Babs" suggested this place and I must admit that I was skeptical given I have never read a review of this place nor seen it on the many top restaurant list I religiously study.  We went before seeing smart , witty,and full of rage Jeneane Garofalo at Cobb's a few weeks back.  The space was airy and relaxing despite how small it was.  Decoration was minimal and it is also easy to miss from the outside.  We started by sharing the generously portioned carrot soup and  it was simply delicious.  Who would have predicted carrot soup to be exceptional but believe me, it was.  We then had mussels in a tasty broth and ribs covered with a strange sauce.  We then shared a fish entree which was also yummy.  The restaurant prides on it support and practice of being green and using organic ingredients.  I would definitely recommend this place and intend to return.  It was quiet on Sunday night with only a few diners so also did appreciate that the noise level was minimal allowing for conversation without having to scream like at many restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Jac C.

description:
This is the first review that I am writing on Yelp. I have loved the site and used it countless times to carefully select restaurants; however, not until now have I had such an extreme experience at a restaurant that I was compelled to write a review. This was one of the worst dining experiences that I have had. I went to Roots for Thanksgiving dinner this year. I was looking forward to the organic holiday meal. I am sad to say that I left with a light wallet and half-empty stomach. 

Let's start from the beginning. I called for a reservation, but had to leave a message with the hotel concierge because there was no one available in the restaurant to answer the phone. I should have known then, but assuming it is Thanksgiving and they are probably busy, with my sights set on an Organic Thanksgiving meal, I made my reservation on Open Table. I wanted to eat at 4:00, but could only get in at 3:00. I again figured this was due to my late planning and happily accepted the 3:00pm time. Upon arriving at the restaurant, I learned this was solely due to poor management. I arrived at the restaurant to find it almost completely empty - only one table with 4 people at it sitting in the entire place. During the entire two and a half hours that I was there, the restaurant never reached more than half of its capacity. My meal continued on its downhill course. It was about 50 degrees outside and despite 4 requests to keep the half-empty restaurant door closed, the staff made no attempt to accommodate. Additionally, upon the most enthusiastic wine recommendation â" our waitress said it was the accompanying bottle with our price-fixed menu â" we purchased a bottle of wine. It was practically undrinkable. We ordered separate glasses and drinks to try to find a somewhat enjoyable drink to accompany our meal â" nothing worked. If efforts not to be rude, we took the 3/4th full bottle of wine with us and threw it out in the trash half way up the block. The night went on with rushed service, mediocre food and arguably partly-frozen dessert. We laughed and made the best of it until the bill. Our waitress brought out dessert as another course in our preset menu, but then charged us for two desserts. What an outrage! All in all, I will never go back to this place and would not recommend it to anyone.
author: Alexis P.
